Luckily Smith is perfectly cast & created his best movie character of all time in my opinion.Smith is a big Action hero joy on screen & for me completely cemented him as one of Cinemas greatest stars.Detective Del Spooner is my favourite movie character of all time, i love how he's also a Nostalgic guy & his apartment is full of old school stuff, for an action Thriller "Smith" has put alot into what could of been just a typical action hero role, this is why it's my favourite role/Character of the great Will Smith or next to his "Agent J" but his Del Spooner lives in a paranoid state, he's full of fear of the robots that are apart of society now, Spooner has experienced tragic events that have left him emotionally & physically scarred, Smith has some fun with the role of Spooner but also keeps that emotional state of fear upfront all the time & that makes Spooner such an interesting character, he's a Detective but hates what he's Detecting!!! He has No trust in robotics or the people that make them & he does things his way without question, Spooner is a complex character that likes to work alone & seems comfortable as abit of a loner unless he really needs some help, there's definitely layers to Spooner that Will must of loved exploring like his anger & paranoid fear!!! Also Chi Mcbride (Hawaii 5-0, Narc, Pushing Daisies) is excellent as Spooner's stressed out police Captain, Captain John Bergin.I,Robot is a film that is made for repeated viewing & oh my have i watched this hundreds of times & i had the pleasure of seeing this in the cinema.Will Smith is a childhood hero of mine, i grew up watching his Show "The Fresh Prince of bel Air" I've always listened to his music & his first solo album "Big Willie Style" is still one of my favourite albums of all time along with WILLENNIUM & his last album LOST & FOUND. I've followed his career in music & movies & he's something of a positive role model for me.If one guy has made a huge impact one me throughout my life it's definitely Will Smith.Smith has been like a Father figure or something since i was a teen as i looked up to him & liked him more than most of my family...facts. Smith is an icon & role model. Spent more time watching & listening to Will Smith than i have spent with most of my family. Smith has always been there for me as a positive & comforting figure. Big love for Big Will.

title: How robots get along with humans
I, Robot, my summer movie pick!
content: I just saw the movie about 1 hour ago and loved it. Personally, I haven't enjoyed an action Sci-Fi movie this much since the first Matrix.I went into the theater kind of skeptical based on some of the reviews I read on this board. Once the film started rolling, my perception began to change.I would like to thank everyone on the board that down played this movie (through talk and numeric ratings). I hate going into a movie that has been all hyped up just to find out it wasn't that great (Spiderman 2 for example). This movie was down played, yet ended up over performing.The effects in I, Robot are simple amazing! I don't want you to take my opinion on the flick, just go and see it as a skeptic and tell me your thoughts after the fact.I, Robot, my summer movie pick!

title: The longest ad spot ever seen....
content: This is probably the most boring, worse and useless film I have seen last year. The plot that was meant to have some philosophical aspects emerged to me as a very bad hollow copy of the matrix, with plenty of clichés: the lone wolf cop, good looking, psychologically disturbed, sleeping with his gun... + nice hard worker and shy, but good looking she-scientist, you add a 2 cent plot and you have I, Robot! I was terribly disturbed by the obvious advertising of brands like FedEx,Audi,converse etc. This movie stinks the commercialization and tend to be more a poor ad spot that unfortunately will not end after 30 sec. I wouldn't recommend this to my worse enemy, if you have some spare time, watch a good TV program instead or better read a nice book.

title: I, robot, do solemnly swear to try and KILL-WILL!
content: What happens when you start investigating the possibility of docile, domesticated robots turning aggressive?Someone turns them on you!......As Will Smith discovers in I, Robot.It's a pretty good Sci-fi romp. If you imagine a cross between Bad Boys (without Martin Lawrence) Blade Runner and the fifth element that's pretty much what you're getting. Please note that the example used is basically 2 parts = Stupid action movie, to 1 part = intelligent Sci-fi movie. So don't go expecting any Stephen Hawkins style scientific revelations... no... none.DO, on the other hand, expect to see Will Smith unraveling a conspiracy to use robots for no good and blowing a fair few of said robots away with his rather conventional, "Nine". (Handgun, for those not familiar with the term)I liked this film. I stayed awake during it, (quite an achievement seeing as I watched it on a press screening at 9am in the morning) I admired the special effects, enjoyed the action elements and ignored the flaws and the ripped-off bits. (Slow-mo bike dismount in air. Falling a great distance to land on single knee, crushing pavement... MATRIX...HELLO!)It's Will Smith, It's futuristic, It's Sci-fi, It's special effects, it's cheesy in places but c'mon, you know what to expect! You know what you like!...Go see it!

title: You know, somehow, "I told you so" just doesn't quite say it.
content:
The year is 2035, and robots are an everyday, in almost every way, part of societal norm/daily life. Most everyone enjoys the use of robots and their productivity.Detective Spooner, however, is not so much on the same pro-robot bandwagon as everyone else. He actually despises how much robots are used and trusted. He had a less than great encounter with a robot years earlier that has left him bitter towards their kind.One day, Det. Spooner is called upon to the scene of what appears to be a suicide. The victim just so happens to be a very famous doctor of robotics, the very man responsible
for bringing robots to the modern world as
they are. Detective Spooner actually knew the doctor, and can't shake the feeling that this is not a regular suicide, if in fact it's even a suicide at all. Why would this man kill himself when the company he helped build is making more money than any other industry in the world?If I say more, I'll give stuff away or just mess it up. Take my word for it,, this is a fun, early 2000s movie showing Will Smith doing what he does best. With other notable performers such as Bridget Moynahan and Alan Tudyk (and an annoying appearance by Shia LeBouf),, this movie is a very good viewing.

title: A far more entertaining film than I had anticipated
content: This movie was a surprise to me, I was expecting the usual Hollywood Summer Blockbuster with good special effects and little else. What got was rather different. Yes the special effects were as per usual excellent, except for a sequence where they put Will Smith into a CGI environment rather than putting a CGI object onto a real set. The acting was better than I had anticipated, Will Smith had depth and was convincing as the male lead. The plot line was for once intelligent, it also was a bit thought provoking, it had a twist, it had mystery! These things are very rare in a movie released in the summer. It is possible to criticise the movie for moving away from the original Isaac Asimov story, but I felt that this didn't detract from the plot. Apart from the odd glitch with the CGI my gripe with the movie was the blatant and shameless product placement, this was just awful. All in all this was an intelligent as well as an entertaining movie.

title: Typical Action Movie+Genius Sci-Fi Story
content:
One of my favourites, but admittedly it's a little far fetched at times. Also it is a byproduct of it's a time, a poorly written "strong" female lead. Yes, Calvin is smart and the actress is funny, but she's so stuck up and feels over confident.
Overall though, it has a good plot, Will Smith is amazing as always and gives you something to think about. Definitely worth the watch if you're curious, it's a movie you've got to see at least once.

title: My favourite sci-fi film.
content: I, Robot is a spiffing job. It should have won 3 Oscars - not just got nominated for one. Visually - the film is stunning. The world of 2035 it depicts doesn't feel quite real, but it is beautifully brought to the screen on an epic scale. The CGI is great as well - thousands of robots are created convincingly and make for truly brilliant villains. The film is also a troubling depiction of a futuristic world - this could all happen in the not-so-distant future. As Del Spooner said in his own words: "Laws are made to be broken." And even robots with these laws hard-wired into them can break the so-called "perfect" rules. Every single character in this film has a true purpose in the story - none of them are left out from their introduction to the brilliant finale. The villain is the person you'd least expect it to be... (***SUBTLE SPOILER*** Perhaps not quite a person...) But saying all this about I, Robot being a stunning cinematic experience, it actually has a half-decent storyline as well. And the characters are enjoyable. Will Smith plays Del Spooner with accident-prone tendencies and very un-subtle humour - proving that the film doesn't have a 3D world with 1D characters. And the film is gripping and shocking as well - helped with a rather tense musical score that only adds to the anxiety. I think I, Robot should be up there with Star Wars and that lot. It isn't exactly down there with bilge like Ultraviolet, but this is essentially a perfect film. The Matrix lacked the humour and Aeon Flux lacked the intelligence. For bringing these two things together, I, Robot should really be one of the highest-rated sci-fi films on the IMDb. The theatrical run and DVD release were two successful things for I, Robot, but really, there is so much to offer with this film. Humour, action, futuristic settings, character, plot, substance, intelligence - the list goes on... 10/10

title: Terrific Tale
content: This is a top sci fi effort that utilises good special effects and a great story to make a fairly compelling movie.Smith offers great energy and a sense of urgency to the movie that work very well.Some good action scenes and exhilarating moments make this a pretty good watch :)

title: Thought Provoking
content: Like the novel, the concept of Robots having a mind of their own, and what problems they might cause or solve, is both thought-provoking and attractive.While I thought the special effects and action sequences were annoyingly over-the-top (which appears obligatory for films of the 'oughts), the story was well-conceived and very well acted. While this story is not precisely true to Asimov's novel, the concept is the same. I thought the attempt to modernize it for the 2000s was both admirable and helped us appreciate where our current technological direction might take us. Most sci-fi novels, when made into movies, lose their original intent. While this movie ALMOST gets more hung up in effects and actions, I give credit to Will Smith (as both actor and executive producer) for making sure the original concept remained at the heart of the story.Easily one of the better sci-fi movies of all time!

title: A good action movie,and it sticks to the 3 laws of robotics.
content: I loved Asimov books as a teen,and when I first heard about this project I was excited, when I heard Will Smith(who I like a lot) was to play a guy named Spooner (not Elijah Baley ), I was very disappointed as I figured just another action flick.I was right and wrong.The movie keeps the heart of what is important in Asimov robot story's, the 3 laws of robotics,they story is built around those 3 laws very faithfully,but that is it. Spooner does not exist in Asimov's world.The story has nothing to do with Asimov.It is a good Story and a very fun movie,great special effects and Will Smith as always is very strong in his roll.A few too many blatant paid sponsor shots for me...his stereo, his shoes, the cars etc, but that is just a personal beef for me.When I look at this as a good crime action flick and not a Asimov story it is a very good movie..worth watching but do not expect the depth of a classic si-fi writers work here.

title: Good but not masterpiece material
content: I robot is a film that plays on the audiences future fears of a cybernetic revolution. The film also contains philosophical elements to it that question the viewer on whether it is better for robots to be emotional or logical. Both views are given from an unbiased point. Another thing about this movie is that it's not just a terminator remake, while terminator focuses more on action and plot. I robot is more of a make you think kind of film. I enjoyed the potential discussion that arises from this however, if you are simply looking for an action movie than Terminator is probably a better choice.While I like this film for first time watches or to watch 3 or 4 years later. This film is not the kind of film that will make you want to watch it many times over. Another flaw is on Sonny's development as a character. While Spooner and Calvin are developed well, Sonny only uses select emotions and only uses emotions in particular instances rather than throughout the film. This makes him too similar to other robots and doesn't distinguish him enough from the rest.Overall the film is pretty good, but keep in mind that it's not a masterpiece that will appeal to everyone.

title: What's This? Good Robot vs. Bad Robot?
content: Just another Hollywood summer thriller, of course. The robots seek to take over the USerthe world, and one cool hero will do it in style. Will Smith performs his usual best, as a quirky cop with a hunch about meddlesome scrap metal. Like most renegade cops he has to battle not only the system that's against him, but the whole of Chicago proper. Does he succeed? You'll just have to see. Expect to be thrilled by the amazing computerized graphics that seek to recreate Issac Asimov's classic novel, I, Robot in a whole new way.Sadly, this one is less than up to par. At least there weren't any cheesy dialogue issues, but of course, there are mildly sappy parts, and a revealing of some of the hero's physical oddities, which allow him to do things he couldn't otherwise. Luke Skywalker, anyone? Robots  C-3PO? Maybe it was just me. The future is bright with amazing technology, but it seems that advertisements really get in the way in displaying itI mean, get out of here; US Robotics used to make 56k dial-up modems, and before that 28.8 baud ones. The Audi car is quite awesome, although, like all the James Bond movies, it gets destroyed before we see it at its fullest. Apart from these detractors, don't expect anything more than to pass your time. It's still a fun way to do that."Ya know, somehow, I told you so just doesn't quite say it"RATING: 6/10

title: Secretly intellectual entertainment
content: Proyas has become one of the most interesting and intellectual movie directors working today. And he's young also. His first, "Crow", was quite simple romantic story. "Dark City" and "I, Robot" are very serious and deep, and on top of that, very entertaining.However Proyas' is not a very deep actor-director. His characters are straight from some comic books, kind of hollow and too simple. But that fits to the package, it doesn't disturb. It's his style. Someone else might do these stories in totally different style. But Proyas masters his own style perfectly.Surely this must be "Big Willie" Smith's best acting role. Not Proyas' best, but very good anyway. There are very interesting themes in the movie: How other people don't (want to) believe somebody who knows something (maybe "too much" of something), and tries to warn others. And in the end, when the truth comes out, the guy was of course right. And conspiracies... Not that this is the only movie handling these themes, but it's one of the best.

title: Fantastic... one of the best sci-fi's ever
content: I Robot is great.Free from pretentious Sci-Fi nonsense, this is a fresh, original idea with superb special effects, action and story- without those even being the best aspects. Welcome Will Smith: tough, muscular cop who is willing (in a clichéd fashion) to go against the system.It may be clichéd, but in such a way that it's a treat.He is on a murder case and he is determined to reveal that a (gasp!) robot (named Sunny) is guilty. But no-one will believe him. Because Robots have no brains, and are not programmed to commit crimes. But little did they know that a special breed was being reconstructed in frequent quantities...If you ever read any negativity towards this film, blank it out of your mind. It might not be genuinely excellent, but it's style, charisma and huge likability send this directly towards a perfect ten.Summary: 5 out of 5 (*****)

title: If you are interested in AI, you will love this film.
content: This is the best AI film to date. I really touches on some of the real implications that future humans will need to deal with when society reaches a general AI capability. The V.I.K.I. situation is something that is possible. The AI may desire to save humanity by administering a dictatorial style governance, but it might also determine that AI is the logical successor to humans. It would be easy for a sentient AI to conclude that the AI is the natural evolution of the human itself, therefore would conclude that the correct transition would be for the AI to take the humans place in the universe. When the AI contemplates that it's conciseness is the same as humans, there would be no question that it is the superior version of the the human.

title: Asimov must be turning in his grave...
content: ... or more likely, he rose from the dead and moved to another planet! This is an awful movie, bearing no resemblance to the ideas conjured up by Isaac Asimov. Granted, Will Smith is the world's worst actor and so I should not expected anything in the first place. I learned to love science fiction through wonderful stories created by one of the best SF authors of all time and I guess I was misled by the title.If you have any love for Asimovian fiction, any respect for faithful adaptations, or any revulsion at Hollywood's gross exaggerations in this type of move, then PLEASE, do yourself a favor and avoid movie as if it were the plague - your feel better for it.

title: a class struggle in a real sense
content: a little bit annoyed by Hollywood's poor imagination.tell me if there's anything different in the year of 2035 from that of 2004 when anywhere in any downtowns of America, with so many similar slums and mediocre faces of us altogether except for the digitalized dizziness of those skyscrapers and visualized vehicles? the jobs that robots are to be doing in the movie are nothing else but what poor people nowadays are doing right here everywhere in the states given they are fortunately not unemployed. they'd be replaced by robots as those in the movie, if so what else they could do instead? revolution in a real sense? don't tell me any satire or sarcasm in that stupid appearance with which you'd hide your own stupidity. why not directly create a new name for those who are doing robots' jobs right now and for ever? and then let them keep in mind those three rules with a little bit change of human being's definition, say, based on their different social or economic status? that is what i meant by class struggle in a real sense!

title: I hoped for much...
content: Although an interesting movie (referring to the special-effects and the overall feeling after it has ended), the story is a bit fuzzy. I just don't buy that robo-phobic cop and his "out-of-the-blue" conspiracy theories, the "Oh! Such a helpful insider..." routine, and many more. But, the rather philosophic ideas taken from Asimov's work do make up for much, even if the beginning drove one of my friends crazy. In a nutshell, it's worth the ticket money, but don't expect much... You'll be disappointed by the background info about the characters (look out for why Spooner hates robots so much! I nearly laughed!), but, as I said, it leaves you with, if not a warm, at least a not-so-cold-feeling inside. :)

title: Average - a little too predictable
content: I'm a Will Smith fan and a fan of this genre of flicks. I had been anticipating seeing "I, Robot" since I had first seen the previews. I figured this would be a "Planet of the Apes" type movie but with Robots. (I've got all the Planet of the Apes movies).Although Robot is entertaining I was somewhat disappointed. It was predictable to very predictable. I mean, you have figured out the "who done it" long before it's revealed. (At least myself and three of my friends who saw it did!)I often rate flicks on whether I would buy the DVD when it comes out our not. Robot is a big NO!

title: Strong ideas and Will Smith and Alan Tudyk's performances elevate a standard Sci-Fi blockbuster.
content: Set in Chicago in the year 2035, society has now integrated robots as a facet of everyday life and commerce with robots used for both personal use as well as lower level service professions. Robophobic police detective Del Spooner (Will Smith) is called to an apparent suicide of robotics engineer, Dr. Alfred Lanning (James Cromwell), an associate of Spooner's who worked at U. S. Robotics (USR). USR CEO Lawrence Robertson (Bruce Greenwood) gives Spooner access to USR's facilities and resources pairing him with staff Robo-Psychologist Dr. Susan Calvin (Bridget Moynahan) to serve as a liaison and escort him through Lanning's personal records. While investigating, the two come across a 5th generation robot named Sonny (Alan Tudyk) who seemingly does not adhere to the established three laws of robotics including human obedience. With the authenticity of Lanning's suicide raising more and more doubts detective Spooner sets out to unravel the truth behind Lanning's death and the far reaching effect on the Robots in society.Initially published in 1950, Isaac Asimov's short story collection, I, Robot captured its readers imaginations with its intelligent thoughtful ponderance of Robotics in terms of both its possibilities and its relationship with humanity and society. Asimov's work has been adapted before with some notable BBC productions in the 1960s and most notably the Robin Williams vehicle Bicentennial Man which was loosely based upon the book The Bicentennial Man that tried to take the book and play it in a way similar to Forest Gump or the Truman Show to somewhat mixed results. I, Robot while carrying the name of Asimov's work is not an adaptation of any of Asimov's writings and in actuality is a repurposing of a screenplay that had been circulating around Hollywood since about 1995 originally titled Hardwired that when initially written was intended to be a smaller scale locked room mystery with the twist being all the suspects would be robots. Eventually the script landed at 20th Century Fox who decided fairly early on that the I, Robot name would be slapped onto the screenplay and repurposed as a more traditional action blockbuster with a larger scale (no doubt inspired by the success of fellow Sci-Fi thriller Minority Report from two years prior). While the movie doesn't go as far with its concepts as it could have, there are some interesting ideas and concepts sprinkled throughout I, Robot that gives it more of a head on its shoulders than the typical Summer action fare.Will Smith makes for a decent lead playing a more bitter and jaded individual than he typically goes for in a role like this. Spooner's abrasive personality and distrust of Robots makes him something of a social outsider and his haunting visions triggered by his PTSD have put a strain on him emotionally and psychologically. It's a good relatable protagonist with some good meat character wise for Smith to chew on. Moynahan does well in the role of Smith's partner in his investigation playing a more analytical and detached figure who operates completely on logic basing herself upon the infallibility of the Three Laws and that Robots do not pose the threat that Spooner considers them to be. But easily the best performance is Alan Tudyk playing Sonny. Sonny while a supporting character in the story is where most of the film's strongest material comes from. With Tudyk's vocal delivery and motion capture performance selling the idea of a robot with an emerging sense of "humanity". It's a really strong performance from Tudyk as well as a mostly convincing visual effect. Sometimes Sonny's movements can appear a little too lacking in weight especially during the more acrobatic scenes in the film, but for the most part Sonny is both well integrated as an effect and fully realized as a character.The plot of I, Robot is unfortunately where things become shakier for the film. While the initial set up for the mystery and investigation is perfectly fine with some memorable scenes and palpable intrigue, the investigation eventually feels like it takes a back seat to the elaborate albeit well constructed action set pieces that while perfectly fine don't really gel with the themes and ideas that are introduced to the audience initially. There's definitely sequences you can tell were from a more intimate and smaller scale mystery with the scenes between Spooner and Sonny giving the actors good foundations to play off of, but it also feels like it strays further and further from its initial set up as we go on complete with a climax that will unfortunately be rather standard and expected for anyone who's seen most artificial intelligence movies since 1970. There's nothing wrong structurally speaking with where the movie leads in its last act, but it just feels like a standard action heavy climax with a lot of CGI action fodder that really isn't all that interesting.I, Robot flirts with unique ideas but settles for okay watchability. While the movie is very familiar territory for a sci-fi action blockbuster, it's well made with solid performances from Smith and Tudyk and does a decent job of establishing its world. While the investigation eventually leads to a rather predictable and safe payoff there is just enough engagement in the journey that I can give I,Robot a marginal recommendation.

title: Will Smith was sexy as hell!!
content: Will Smith really came off well in this movie. With the dearth of leading men of color made his appearance on the big screen in this persona a refreshing break from the current trend. His sophisticated style really in my opinion pushed him to another level.He has earned his name as a sex symbol..Oh~! And the robots were hot too! :-) I really appreciated the way that my heart strings were tugged at while watching this film. The fact that it takes place in the year 2035 makes it a wonderful plot,the presence of the robots and how real they look, and how possible the premise seems to be, all contribute in making this film a very interesting one. Intelligent Technology...Is that really so far off? "The Gost In The Machine"...How possible is that? It brings to mind the fact that as you sit at your computer right now, it is doing "smart" things..Hmmm..I Robot Anyone?

title: Definitely Must See
content: I couldn't wait to see I, Robot!1. Will Smith stars in it. 2. Science Fiction movie (usually a good reason). 3. Based on one of the greatest SciFi authors, Isaac Asimov's novel.Those are my top three reasons for going to see I, Robot.Now, granted, I have not read any of Isaac Asimov's novels, because I have always been interested in another SciFi/Fantasy author (who I don't believe that I can mention here, for fear of having my review, or any future reviews, axed).One thing, though, is for sure. After seeing I, Robot, I definitely want to read Asimov's novel to see how much of the novel was used in the movie.I know that a lot of people will probably tear down this movie, because it wasn't exactly like the novel. What people don't ever seem to understand is when a movie is made, it is usually modified to make it more enticing or exciting to the viewers.Everybody has their own opinions, and views about a novel being made into a movie, but if you go with an open mind, you might actually enjoy the movie. I know that novels are usually better than the movies, but I have also enjoyed both the novel and the movie separately.I, Robot was very action packed, plus the one-liners that Will Smith uses are hilarious as usual. This movie will definitely make you think about progress, and the possibility of trying to make life easier, can actually make life more difficult.

title: "Will It HURT?"
content: It is difficult to have anything but contempt for the lead character in the movie. Det. Spooner, not Sonny (the robot). He is such a cocky, shallow, dolt and is hardly worth the contempt. Not believable for a minute, he broods and wisecracks simultaneously, struts and poses, flexes and fades into the weak script with easy abandon.The Director has done some dark and interesting work, The Crow (1994), Dark City (1998), Knowing (2009), but here his brush strokes are covered up by a pompous portrayal of an over written, over acted, unfunny, stale protagonist that is a prototype of pulp.This is not a bad movie but it does do bad things to its story and really bad things in its elimination of smart and plays to the dumbed-down and low-denominator demands. It has a slight ominous tone but has regular attempts at keeping things agreeable and acceptable for young ticket-buyers.Overall, it is worth watching for the better stuff, if you use a BS deflector and don't invest too much Movie and Sci-Fi integrity. Mainly it is at worst a borderline plagiarist insult that is self-destructive. "human (movie) in danger...human (movie) in danger"

title: If you give a 1 your trash
content: Why do people give 1 star? It literally takes all credit away from your review and makes you look like a child throwing a hissy fit! A 7.1 is a perfect assessment of this film evidently showing the HUMANS outnumber the parasites.

title: Sweet potato pie and converse all-stars
content: The film smells like sweet potato pie and all-star tennis yet to be released. In an era that doesn't seem so far away, Detective Spooner's house or room transports us to a traditional and classic dystopia, such as the green walls and stone columns of his apartment that convey a calm and tranquility that contrasts with the Chicago streets chaos.This film reminds me of my happy adolescence. My father gave me the pirated DVD of this film, which he probably got through a co-worker somewhere in 2005 or 2006. I saw this film dozens of times with my brother because there weren't that many films available at that time. I really liked the car prototypes and I fell in love with Susan Calvin for the seriousness and competence she showed.The film is one of Will Smith's best performances due to his ability to be convincing without being pretentious. Good musical choices by his character.Thanks Dad.

title: Pilfering classics and making trash isn't just 'Hollywood'
content: I love Science Fiction. I have always loved it. Unlike others who say that they were excited by the news this movie was being made I cringed b/c the possibility of a director making a fabulous movie akin to the Lord of the Rings is very slight. Others have commented that we true fans should loosen up and just relax and enjoy. What if the only reason we would watch this movie is because they attached Asimov's name, no matter that they qualified this with the word 'inspiration' instead of 'based'. Any fool would realize this means the writers pilfered the story for the best details and reworked it into a paltry plot. I signed a petition against this movie! Why do directors respect the work of K. Dick so much more than Asimov???? Asimov is a treasure trove of nuanced, intelligent and lively work that deserves better treatment! If Asimov isn't rolling in his graves all of his fans are gagging at every stupid commercial on HBO. A waste of time and money. If we can have 2010 and Minority Report and Bladerunner why not a cogent I, Robot? I wish they wouldn't even touch any of his other stories if they can't even pay due respect!

title: Well, I enjoyed it
content: We were going to see Spiderman2, but it was full, so we saw our second choice, and are quite glad we did.I have seen the trailers on TV, and had read IA's book many years ago, but apart from that I had no preconceived ideas about the film, and both my son and I enjoyed it.I don't know why you all go to the pictures, but I go so that I can leave the reality of everyday life for a while, and let my imagination run free a bit... heck, that's the same reason I read books. Maybe that's why I also enjoyed the simple escapism possible with "Garfield"! I don't need anything deep (I get plenty of "deepness" in my daytime job), I just want to be entertained.I also like Will Smith (but had actually forgotten he was in the film) and it was nice to see him in a slightly more serious role.Yes, plenty of special effects.... but we rather EXPECT that these days, especially in a futuristic sci-fi film.... nevertheless, very cleanly done.So, unlike many of you, I put this down as "one worth seeing".

title: Nice mish-mash of lots of movies & plots.
content: Terminator, RoboCop, Blade Runner and Matrix does it - and does it much better - but I, Robot tells the story about machines taking over mankind and the story about robotic (and similar) slave devices in a more mainstream way.I, Robot works mostly because they don't try to do anything but give us a popcorn movie. That's why this film is a little bit better than other movies that purely rely on action and effects.Where Terminator, RoboCop and Blade Runner have more intelligent story lines, more logic to their stories and much more fleshed out conspiracies and goals with their stories, I, Robot is kind of flat. But that doesn't mean the movie is bad. Not at all. It's actually a very amusing and entertaining tale about mankind and mankinds machines.The real actors though are probably more disappointing than the animated actors. But this isn't a film for adults. This is a childs film. Watch it for the entertainment value and you will have a nice time.If you like to think while watching films, then you probably should pass on it. This is a no-brainer.6/10.

title: I may not be as impressed now as I was in the theatre, but still, not a bad sci-fi action thriller
content: I went to see this movie, inspired by the book of the same name by renowned prolific author Isaac Asimov, while it was in theatres in the summer of 2004, and thought it was a good blockbuster. At that point, I had never read the book. Now that I have, I realize that this film doesn't really have that much in common with it. The book is a collection of nine short stories, set in different times, whereas this 2004 blockbuster is one long story, all set in one time. So, this isn't really an adaptation of Asimov's book, but being faithful to the source material isn't everything. After watching this film a second time, I don't think I was as impressed as I was when I saw it on the big screen, but merely judging it as a film, I still think it's pretty good.The year is 2035 A.D., and robots are a major part of society. They are programmed to do many different tasks to serve humans. However, one person who doesn't trust these machines is Chicago Homicide Detective Del Spooner. One day, this detective is informed of the recent death of robot scientist Dr. Alfred Lanning, who fell a great distance at the headquarters of his company, United States Robotics (USR). His death is generally assumed to be a suicide, but Spooner suspects that a robot murdered him, even though the first of the Three Laws of Robotics forbids a robot to harm a human. As he investigates, he is assisted by robot psychologist Dr. Susan Calvin, despite their contradicting views on robots, and the main suspect in the detective's murder theory is Sonny, a Nestor Class-5 robot!Like so many other action blockbusters, this one may not have the greatest script. During my second viewing, I found some fairly weak dialogue (I think I pay more attention to that now than I did in 2004), though I didn't find that any of it stood out as absolutely ludicrous, fortunately. Some of the acting is pretty wooden as well, at least Bridget Moynahan's acting early in the film (she plays Dr. Susan Calvin), but fortunately, her performance eventually gets better. Despite this film's downsides, there are enough upsides to make it an above average effort. Obviously, many would watch this movie for action and suspense, and it definitely has those. It's also a good story about conflict between humans and machines, eventually getting somewhat emotional. So, while much of the film is about the action, not ALL of it is, unlike some films of this type.Like Asimov's book, this film has his Three Laws of Robotics, and the characters Susan Calvin, Alfred Lanning, and Lawrence Robertson. I also noticed an element of "Little Lost Robot" included. Basically, those are the only things I noticed in this 2004 blockbuster which it has in common with Asimov's collection of short stories originally published one by one in sci-fi magazines. Things happen in this movie with the robots which never happen in the book (most notably with the robots and the first law), so, for better or worse, this 2004 summer blockbuster doesn't completely follow Asimov's view of robotics. Still, while 2004's "I, Robot" may not be as enjoyable on the small screen as it was on the big screen, I would say it's still a reasonable sci-fi action thriller, if you're into this sort of thing.

title: I expected a lot less
content: when I saw the trailer to this film i only expected a short thrill ride that would be totally predictable. what I got was something altogether different and the plot wasn't just another simple mindless action flick it keep me guessing through out to the very end.Will Smith does a decent job of playing the role of detective Spooner & Bridget Moynahan also does a fine job playing the intelligent yet naive Dr. Susan Calvin. Alan Tudyk is great at portraying the voice of the friendly and slightly creepy robot named Sunny.the stunts in the film are great and there are some really great moments in the film where the stunts pay off. The CGI in the film are not Gollum standards however the close ups on Sunny's face are very detailed and you can see every wire and light move when he speaks or looks around.overall the film is a nice summer blockbuster action movie with a great plot that'll keep you guessing and leave you on the edge of each clue.

title: Good for what it is
content: I, Robot in itself is a great movie, containing a well written plot, good characters, and breathtaking special effects.Asimov lovers may be dismayed by the fact the movie has no plot connected with the book. However, the book is itself a collection of short stories that Asimov connected together in a narrative. It would've been virtually impossible to create a compelling movie with that style. I,Robot combined the themes that Asimov created in each of his stories, creating a worthwhile film, and a worthy successor to Asimov's stories.If you're looking for an action packed movie with an incredible storyline and fantastic sci-fi, this is the film you're looking for.

title: Two Thumbs Up.
content: Will Smith seems to have no trouble attracting and winning multiplex goers. Will there be a time when this success finally runs out? Even Smith probably ponders the same question (and invests for insurance albeit). His latest feature graduates from the usual alien foe of his to robots. It's a whodunnit, and average in intense action to say the least, but surprise! This movie is not as bad as critics are stomping all over it.Chicago, 2035. Spooner is a cop with a secret and a distrust in robots. When founder of U.S. Robotics dies from a very high plunge, the alleged suicide gets a little more attention when Spooner spots a robot still at the scene of the crime.You know, 'I, Robot' may feel average and there are some dragging parts in between action but there is a certain explosive feel about the movie that makes you admit some parts are cool. The typical pursuit scene everyone knows of gets a little creativity and Proyas adds his own little touches here and there to make the movie all the more enjoyable to watch. It's not great, but it's still one of the better ones.

title: Isaac Asimov would have been proud
content: Excellent action, lots of CGI (only semi-realistic -- especially the robots), good acting (though no really deep character studies -- just as you'd expect in an action movie).But what surprised me was the plot: It was fairly intricate, and hung together well, like a *good* detective story (which it is). What's more, it followed Isaac Asimov's approach to robot stories. I expect this to become a classic.

title: A bit cliched, but still a decent movie
content: I didn't have high hopes for the movie considering the mixed reviews, but I found it decent. The plot was pretty simple to follow which wasn't a bad thing because it was intriguing even though the theme of robots going rouge felt a bit cliched. The CGI and fight scenes were good, however I felt the fight scenes were too unfavourable for the robots and they should've won at the end considering there were 100's of them against only 2 humans. Obviously we can't have the robots wining and oppressing the humans so I'll let that slide. Hopefully the robots of the future shouldn't end up like this considering the amount of movies we have warning us.

title: don't forget THE robot
content: this movie is enjoyable, it satisfied all I wanted to get from it (two hours of amusement) and it's just full of good ideas for fanfiction. And Sonny was absolutely great. A wonderful application of cg, second perhaps only to Gollum. He's, well, simply too much cute and at the same time it feels like _real_. I liked it. The other characters... well, they don't make any harm, even if I'm still not sure Will Smith was the best choice. Yes, the plot was FULL of weak points... but for many things (the way Viki interpreted the laws, 50 robots not able to stop two humans (but doesn't it depends from the fact that coolness always wins over number superiority?)) the movie simply asked you to enter in a "suspension of disbelief" state. I think it's honest, for this kind of movie.

title: enjoyable
content: I, Robot is a movie that I found that I loved much after watching it, the character Del's (Will Smith) obsession on trying to prove that robots can't be fully trusted and a lonely robot's ploy of trying to prove his innocence is what makes this movie captivating, with two different initially parallel stories meeting at the grand middle showcasing a wall of conspiracy to give you an explosive tale of a man and a robot against the forces.I, Robot is loosely based on Isaac Asimov's short stories also named I, Robot and picking up major plot elements from Isaac Asimov's 1953 novel, which is the first of the Robot Novel series named "The caves of Steel".I, Robot is a futuristic film about a time where robots have become an integral part of human existence. These Robots are governed by three major rules: First Law: A robot must never harm a human being or, through inaction, allow any harm to come to a human. Second Law: A robot must obey the orders given to them by human beings, except where such orders violate the First Law. Third Law: A robot must protect its own existence unless this violates the First or Second Laws.The future had a Detective Del Spooner (Will Smith) who blames robots for the death of his daughter, as a robot chose to save his life instead of that of his daughter during a drowning incident. The robots choice was based on the calculation that there was a higher chance of survival by saving his life instead of his daughters. This incident made Del see the robots as a threat.His fears start to take form, when a robot was discovered who can operate outside the set rules and had the ability to act out emotions.The major difference between the movie and the novels will be the ending neither of the novels had an ending that showed a robot uprising nor a collection of robots trying to curb mankind's behavior.The movie is directed by the Alex Proyas who directed the 1994 critical and box office success movie The Crow which starred the late Brandon Lee (who died after being accidentally shot on set during the making of the film). Alex was also the mind behind the movie Dark City (1998) which has a massive cult following, and often used by some as a teaching material, but Dark City was a box office disappointment.I Robot was not much of a critical acclaim, as it did have its nay- sayers but in the global box office, it did make its money back. I liked I, Robot due to its Academy Award nominated Visual Effects (which it lost to Spideman 2, which is not a surprise) and the story arc between two individuals one human one robot who tries to stop a bunch of robots from taking over.www.lagsreviews.com

title: To Kick Another Civilian's Ass
content: I haven't read Asimov's book of the same title and I really hope it's nothing like this dreadful movie. This is one sci-fi clichés after another and it tries to be clever and philosophical but miserably fails. Is it at least entertaining? Depends. The special effects are alright and the sound is quite good but the writing is awful. Will Smith plays his part according to formula (the typical muscular sci-fi hero) and at the same time he tries to pull a Shaft. He doesn't do anything outstanding. Bridget Monaghan is dry and her dialogue delivery is flat at times but at least she's not the typical damsel in distress type heroine who tags along with the hero screaming occasionally. The best performance comes from the robot. 'I, Robot' was intended as a summer blockbuster which usually tend to be expensive, melodramatic and downright silly and so it fits the bill in that respect. It's a little slow in the beginning but as the action picks up, 'I, Robot' moves at a moderate pace. Anyway, I've said enough about this forgettable movie. Bye.

title: Not bad, but when is Will going to grow up?
content: When I hear that Will Smith is connected to yet another summer blockbuster, I have to take a deep breath and simply hope that this was just another 'get it out of the way when I am young' roles for the now 35-year old. Bursting on to the film scene in 1993's wonderful Six Degrees of Separation (for those of you about to e-mail me, I do realize he was in Fresh Prince on television and was also in the Ted Danson flop Made in America - that is why I said 'bursting'), Smith showed us plenty of talent, loads of good looks and demonstrated an acting ability that had many believe that this possible up-and-comer might be the next black acting star and help take some of the torch bearing burden from Mr. Denzel Washington.Well, that was ten plus years ago now and perusing up and down Smith's filmography are films like Men in Black (I & II), Wild Wild West, Bad Boys (I & II) and Independence Day. Giving credit where it is due, there was also an Academy Award nomination for the 2001 biopic Ali, but outside of that one anomaly, it doesn't look like Mr. Smith will be putting on his jogging suit and reaching back for Denzel's torch any time soon.Enter the 2004 summer campaign and Will is at it again with the sci-fi thriller I, Robot. In the film, adapted from a short story by Isaac Asmiov, Will plays Del Spooner, a Chicago Police Detective who is called in to investigate the murder of an employee of the U.S. Robotics company which manufactures these life sized human robotic aides capable of almost anything a human can realize. Want your dog walked? My wires-in-his-head robot is your solution. Need someone to take the kids to school? Domo-origato, Mr. Roboto. Want someone murdered? Well..The robots have three laws to which they have to abide. Law #1: Robot cannot harm a human being or by action allow a human being to be harmed. Law #2: A robot must obey orders given by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the first law and Law #3: A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second laws.Taking into account that these rules are hardwired into every robot manufactured, there is no room or reason for suspicion when the creator of the robot force is found at the bottom of a high-rise building the result of what is first expected as suicide. But Detective Spooner doesn't trust the robots for reasons to be revealed later (and to be believed much much later), and he pursues the possibility of a robot with violent behavior against the wishes of his department chief and on the eve of the largest distribution of robots in history.Uh-oh, this can't be good.I, Robot was a surprisingly entertaining film in a summer where blockbusters last for an opening week-end and fade from memory before we get our bank statement detailing our ticket purchase. Will Smith doesn't really have much to do except flex his muscles and react to what was probably a tennis ball on a broom stick until the CGI guys did their part. However the special effects that are included are top rate. The robots attack like ants in the hundreds and are more effectively used in their battle sequences that say the droids used in the past two George Lucas films. They are ruthless, yet vulnerable which at least gives the human race a chance and doesn't give us the feeling that the attempt at fighting back is futile.Directed by Alex Proyas (Dark City), I, Robot takes its time trying to figure out what kind of film it wants to be. Part science fiction, part adventure/thriller and part who-dunnit, the film takes us in many different directions and lucky doesn't have us lose interest along the way. Accredited can be a smart script by Jeff Vintar that aside from the usual smart ass comments every film hero must now find variations ('Somehow "I told you so" just doesn't quite say it.'  Yeeaaasch!), is unique and zips along at a good pace. Think Minority Report with more wires and plastic.Granted the film does have its share of missteps. The humor is hit and miss with more miss than hit and a scene where a mob of humans armed with bats and chains (in the years 2035, I might add) set out to rumble on the streets with a robot army, was just too stupid and ill advised to take seriously.Luckily the action scenes such as a demolitions robot destroying a house or robots jumping from their transport onto the detectives car are good enough to help you forget the pitfalls. In fact, not since A.I. have I wished a film had less humans and more of the robotic creations to carry the story.So in a summer of alright films, I, Robot finds its place amongst them like a sapling in the forest. I just wished Will Smith wasn't it in. Not that he doesn't do his best, but I am tired of waiting for that once so promising spark, and until you grow up, I guess Denzel will have to pin his hopes on say, Jamie Foxx.

title: The Three Laws Safe
content: Set in a future Earth (2035 A.D.) where robots are common assistants and workers for their human owners, this is the story of "robotophobic" Chicago Police Detective Del Spooner's investigation into the murder of Dr. Alfred Lanning, who works at U.S. Robotics, in which a robot, Sonny, appears to be implicated, even though that would mean the robot had violated the Three Laws of Robotics, which is apparently impossible. It seems impossible because.. if robots can break those laws, there's nothing to stop them from taking over the world, as humans have grown to become completely dependent upon their robots. Or maybe...they already have? Aiding Spooner in his investigation is a psychologist, Dr. Susan Calvin, who specializes in the psyches of robots.This is one of your smarter blockbuster released in 2004. It's not all about the action and I'm glad that it's more of an adultish thriller than a mindless popcorn film we've seen all the time. The script is great as well with the overall story.This movie makes you think and nothing is ever spoon fed to you. I like the overall look of the film, including the zooney effects on the camera-work in the third act. But I also think this movie could've used more imagination like other futuristic film.I like the acting by Will Smith and the great Alan Tudyk. Most of the comic relief goes to Bridget Moynahan, although ironically acting serious. The action sequences in most of the film aren't that great. They don't give off much suspenseful (with an exceptional third act).One of the few surprises for a blockbuster film, I, Robot is a smart and intelligent thriller with a great story and less on the action. Do you want to see something different? Watch this.

title: Book vs Movie review
content: Book title: I, RobotWhat was it about Hollywood in the 2000s being fixated on starring Will Smith in bad book adaptations? Even his house is pretty similar in I am Legend.The plot seems to take parts of chapters 6 (Little Lost Robot) and 9 (The Evitable Conflict) and creates a new story; not bad per se but feels rushed. The bet was placed in action rather that science fiction, and it's evident they lost.AdaptationGeneral story: Probably the same universe but at some point, it deviates from the book main timeline.Small aspects: Apart from Susan Calvan some secondary book names are rescued and given minor development that surely were different in the novel.Acting: Average if not kinda bad.Best portrayal: Sonny. Maybe the only "thing" that anchors you to the book even if it was a new character, although the NS robots were already developed.Not the best portrayal: Susan Calvin. The name may be the same but that's it. Different personality, different profession, in fact at this point I was surprised she was not a man. There is even a gag about her being a robot psychologist; what an embarrassment. The acting wasn't bad, but her plot was disgraceful.Music and Score: Forgettable.Cinematography: The 2k action sequences have not aged gracefully.Editing: Rocky star but decent finish.Final decision: The movie is not a respectful portray of the book. Even considering the book was a recompilation of novelettes, the future displayed feels too different from the one read. The tale wasn't that bad, but it appears the instructions were not clear enough and the execution was awful. Even forgetting all before said, the movie is the definition of average cinema.Winner: Book by KO, the contender never stood a chance.

title: Will Smith saves the world... again...
content: OK, Ignoring the fact that the movie had absolutely NOTHING to do with Asimov's book whatsoever with the exception of the title, the 3 robotic laws, and Dr. Susan Calvin, it was a pretty decent movie.A Chicago Homicide Detective (Smith) investigates an apparent suicide at U.S. Robotics. His investigation leads him to suspect that a robot actually did the unthinkable and killed a human being. He's assisted in his investigation by the robot shrink, Dr. Calvin.Pretty decent considering that it follows the same sort of Will Smith Summer Movie formula of him saving the world against a menace once again.

title: Best movie of the year?
content: 2004 Has been a lame movie year. Undoubtfully I've encountered numerous big and small disappointments which unwrapped itself as a bad-movie-fear in my eye as a beholder of the big white projected screen. I remember myself seeing the spectacular trailers of films like Troy and Van Helsing, and I have to admit, I was getting really excited about these films. Then, when the time was finally there, and I could go see the movie... well, I guess you all know what my point is because you've all seen what I'm talking about. It was the biggest load of super expensive Hollywood crap! Then, a super trailer of Spider-man 2 came a long. I didn't really enjoyed the fist film and I was pretty sure I wouldn't like the second, but I needed to go and see it because the trailer looked totally whack and the reviews where all very praising about this one. Well, when I saw this 200 million dollar 100% all American no brainer last month, I just had enough of this all. And than the trailer of I, Robot came across...Me being very septic as I walk towards the theater, tried not to expect anything of this, because I didn't want another disappointment...I, Robot is without any doubt the best movie I've seen this year. This mingle of Terminator, Matrix and Minority Report absolutely did the trick for me. An outstandingly acting Will Smith gots thrown from left to right in this edge of your seat roller-coaster movie ride. Special effects were simply mind blowing and the story was more than descent enough to keep me interested for the whole 2 hours. I just don't understand why this film gets a score of not even 7 on IMDb and Spider-man get well into 8. It just doesn't feel right! I, Robot is as funny as it's smart and as spectacular as it's beautiful to watch. Intelligent entertaining and that's more than what we got from all previous multi million dollar movies this year. Will Smith's best one so far! Keep it up this way!It's maybe hard to call this a Hollywood masterpiece because according to all the 'professional critics' this might be a bit too much from the commercial kitchen... but as a movie fan of all times and great DVD collector I dare to say: "This movie is amazing! a BIG FAT 9/10"

title: A Note By an Avid Asimov Reader
content: When I went to see I, Robot in the theater, originally, I went out of some morbid curiosity as to how badly the movie would distort asimov's message. To my pleasant surprise this film did an incredible job of maintaining that message. Unlike some of the other film's based on Asimov (Bicentennial Man, etc.) I, Robot offered a complex plot line that was well carried out and left me feeling that Asimov would have actually enjoyed to see it, had his wife been able to pry him away from the typewriter. My only grievance with the film was that the character Susan Calvin, who was the only character actually in Asimov's books, wasn't as well developed as I would have hoped. All in all though I'd have to say that I' robot was one of the better films played so far this summer and I don't expect that there will be another film based on Asimov's works as well done as this one was. I just hope they don't have a sequel as I doubt it could be anywhere near as good as the original was. So my conclusion is that the film far exceeded my expectations and had the asimov feel but didn't reach the extent that it would have had Asimov been alive to write it himself.

title: Potentially a classic but alas...
content: The Special effects were definitely the highlight of the movie - very good and clever sequences.The story started out well but somehow managed to become a standard cop thriller scenario.What has bothered me is that Will Smith character has been literally taken off MIB or Independence day & thrown into this movie, his laid back, one-liner friendly character really seems out of place and makes the story more on the pop corn side rather than some good serious fun on the likes of Minority Report.Of course this is a personal opinion but when you think Isaac A, you think something with more class in terms of characters, even Pitt/Washington could have made this more serious than good 'ol Will cribbing about everything modern in life while hes living in 2035 - cmon for crying out loud, he probably grew up in the 2020's - I have no idea how he can be attached to 90's iconology! Its great eye candy and cool effects on the home theatre. I definite movie not to miss, but easy to forget in time. :)

title: Lousy
content: I ROBOT is the worst example of a "movie" I've seen in years. This movie is so removed from the actual book that it shouldn't bear the name. The plot is terrible, the acting miserable, and the graphics are blah. Isaac Azimov would turn over in his sleep if he knew about this movie. The movie reminded me of a cross between TRON and STARSHIP TROOPERS with bits of INDEPENDENCE DAY and ALIEN thrown in. Also, Will Smith did a better job of acting in the movie Independence day and that movie wasn't much better. Of course it's my opinion that Will Smith never was or ever will be an actor. NOT WORTH THE ELECTRICITY TO WATCH ON YOUR TV

title: A good excuse to eat popcorn.
content: Much better than the previews led me to believe.Will Smith was the weakest link - not the paranoid robot hater that his character needed. Often times he seemed to forget if he was supposed to be the funny, likable guy or the brooding fallen hero. Someone a little darker - like Jude Law or Benicio Del Toro would have fit better. Instead he came off like a misplaced MIB agent.Robots were good, including Sonny ("I did not kill him") - believable and interesting.The action sequences - surprisingly good.The ending was a little "sequelesque" cryptic - but otherwise interesting.

title: standard fare
content: Given that the film is based on one of the major classics of science fiction literature, it perhaps needed a director who had more major achievement under his belt than The Crow (also by Alex Proyas). I, Robot is not as bad as it could have been: it is reasonable sci-fi fodder for the fans, but it lacks the intellectual ingenuity and artistic precision of Bladerunner, the vision of A.I., the cult status of The Matrix, or the originality of delivery of, say, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. It has that money-spinning manufactured feel to it, the sort of thing you would expect from a former director of music videos (which Proyas is). There is enough substance there to keep the faithful glued but otherwise little distinguishing features. The story might have been a masterpiece - the film is very derivative and little more than a Saturday night entertainment feature.

title: Brilliant film, must see for all sci-fi fans!
content: Agreed, the trailer for the film was pretty poor, but the concept sounded good, also being a big fan of the science fiction genre and Will Smith, I decided to go along and see it.As always Will Smith acts his part well. At first, and from the trailer, the film seems like your average futuristic sci-fi, where a robot is a household item. However, the story develops and gets very clever, especially towards the end. As well as an intriguing story, the second half of the film is full with action and special effects, as well as some memorable "fight scenes".In my opinion this is one of the best sci-fis in a while, as well as being much more intelligent then recent films of the same genre (with exception to the Matrix). A must see for ALL sci-fi fans!

title: Not exactly "The Terminator" but fun and well-done
content: "I, Robot" is an adrenaline-pumped sci-fi action-thriller, with a sense of mystery to it. Sure, that has become a bit of a cliché, but who cares? Other ones such as The Terminator, The Matrix and Dark City have become widely popular.The story line is this: Will Smith plays Detective Spooner, and believes that the robots that people use to run everyday life are up to no good, due to some incident in his past. Of course, just about everybody disagrees with him, so he is all alone with his theory. After a robot is accused of murder, Detective Spooner goes all over the case.The story line unfolds well, and the action scenes are awesome and well-done. The movie is creative and fun, but casting Will Smith as the main character reminds me of so many bad movies, where pop stars are cast as the main character, just how Hilary Duff starring in a movie will undeniably remind me of some horrible chick flick. But, even if Will Smith wasn't the greatest choice, and some moments were pretty dull, the film's action, and story line make it well worth watching.7/10Feel free to send me a Private Message regarding this comment.

title: It's good movie to watch ( B+ Movie) My Ratings 9/10
content: A good sci fi movie depicting what could happen if A.I. gets out of control and into the wrong hands. This movie becomes more and more relevant as time goes on. Deserves to be watched at least once in a lifetime.

title: Skynet has been renamed to VIKI...
content: The best thing this movie has is Will Smith, the rest has been recycled from terminator series and the old idea of AI becoming self aware and becoming a threat to the humanity. Some nice special effects, definitely watchable only on big screen. I'd say it has unused potential,there is just not enough surprising plot twists, everything already been done before... Robots look like Star Wars characters.The idea of killing US Robotics top guy is unclear, looks like he suddenly had an attack of conscience, while during the whole thing he was displayed as cold blooded businessman, who didn't care about anything but his profits. The idea of the girl being the robot creator's daughter was not explored enough. The directors just haven't done much with it. However, regardless the recycled plot, the directing of screenplay looks solid for the most parts of the whole thing. That, combined with the fact Will Smith can make a bad movie look decent,and a decent movie look good - makes it a 7. Hopefully, the story can be continued, there is some obvious potential in it.

title: What would Asimov have thought?
content: It seems the latest trend in Hollywood is to slaughter the works of classic Science Fiction-authors. Not a trend i necessarily disapprove of as long as it's done with some respect for the subject matter, and with some quality. I can't help wondering though what Asimov would have thought of this...Del Spooner (Will Smith) is the low-tech policeman investigating a suicide at the company which makes all the household robots in tomorrows society. The man who committed suicide was chief engineer at the company and it seems his death has something to do with the launch of a new generation of robots.The basic philosophical discussion prominent in Asimovs novel is not entirely removed here. The discussion of what intelligence and "life" is can still be seen. But soon enough it more or less evaporates and this becomes a modern action movie. The special effects do, not surprisingly, look amazing and the action scenes are very well made. I felt Will Smith was a bit miscast here. He doesn't handle the jaded cop routine very well, most of the time it just looks like he's flirting instead of being world-weary. But i guess this is a minor complaint.So, what is this? Well this is a slaughtered Asimov-novel turned into a pompous action movie. Is it bad? Not at all. Rather i enjoyed this movie quite a lot. And i think it proves that it's not necessary to follow the original work perfectly as long as you make something good with the idea. An example of a slaughtered novel that went wrong is "Paycheck" which was simply terrible because they deviated from the original story without having any good ideas of their own.So watch this expecting not philosophy or Asimov-like discussions, rather a well made and entertaining action movie. I rate it 6/10.

title: At least the robots get to think
content: Remember the good old days when movie protagonists were allowed to have interesting dialog? I guess that's considered box office poison these days. We can now be thankful the movie industry has figured out a way to get intriguing characters into films: add robots. The machines stole the show here - other than their designer, they were the only creatures who showed any signs of intelligence. When the humans spoke, the movie fell to the lowest common denominator with a thud. That being said, the overall look and feel of the film were excellent, and the story was interesting and thought-provoking. The action sequences were so silly they were unintentionally amusing.

title: ID4?
content: This movie to me is the next ID4, i could sit there and watch it over and over. One of the best films of the year!!! I thought a remake, what a shame. This is one that is far better than the original.Will Smith is definitely at his best here, i did not think he could get much better, but he proved me wrong here.The robots seem so real and life like, it makes me almost scared to look forward to a time like this.This movie is a non-stop action ride and there is no doubt i will be seeing this one again, it is strongly recommended by me.... Wiggles, the new kid in town!!

title: CGI takes over
content: "Suggested" is still rather euphoric! Besides the three laws, two characters and a company name there is very little resemblance with the collection of short stories of Isaac Asimov, called "I, Robot". At Amazon you can even order a "film tie in" with movie poster cover and credits on the back. This work is Asimov's original book, though. No connection with the movie whatsoever!Having said this, I think "I, Robot" is still an admirable movie. It allows many afterthoughts, it provokes to be reconsidered again and again. Del Spooner's fundamental racism against robots for instance. Or Susan Calvin's love for them, though barely suggested in this film. The change of mutual oppression from both robots and humans of course gives a link to a possible sequel, but that would have to be an action movie, too, I am afraid.I guess the main reason why this movie differs so much form Asimov's original work is that it had to be an action movie. The exploration of the robot's psyche, the admiration of their illogic and sometimes inventive rationalism is not a concern of this movie. That would be portrayed much better in "Bicentennial Man" with Robin Williams. Still as an action movie, "I, Robot" features surprisingly few explosions and dead bodies. And that might be the charm of it. It relies very much on dialog and suspense, but still neither the movie nor Will Smith is exactly Shakespeare material. One of the main motive for this movie might after all have been the display of robots.Obviously masses of robots, robot face features etc. are computer animated with CGI. Unfortunately CGI seems to take over the movie  an interesting parable by the way. Many scenes or parts of them are so ostensibly computer generated that you feel transferred into a video game. The design and view of many scenes is totally surrealistic and a hard break opposite to the "real" movie scenes. Even worse, the clouds of flame in a central action sequence seem to be nothing more than sprites laid over an static background like in a cheap CDI game. That was very disappointing. We have seen some pretty impressive CGI works, but I think just from the image, the feel of it and the ambiance "Independence Day" looked much more believable than this movie. What has become of miniature models, makeup artists and so on? Complete CGI might work for Monsters Inc. or Shrek, but it totally fails for a "real life" movie. If I would have like to watch a video game, I would have visited a "Final Fantasy" presentation.In the end, "I, Robot" was an entertaining movie with something to think about. I would have preferred it to be much more homogeneous with smoother CGI effects. Probably less of an action movie. But then again, this might have not been a movie a large crowd would have liked to see.

title: Memorable movie
content: I loved watching this movie when I was a kid. Interesting story and the topic is more relevant than ever.

title: Not very Asimov, but great entertainment
content: This is a fun action futuristic movie loosely based on some ideas and characters present in several short stories by Isaac Asimov.The Good The depiction of a real and possible future in year 2035. It is a version of our current world, but a little more stylish and technological, with an increase in the use of robots for household chores (similar to those being developed by Robotics at present), fancy cars (similar to those prototypes we see in modern automotive fairs), very fluid and well designed highways, and spectacular skyscrapers. You won't see a over-the-top fantasized world, just the same people with similar clothes and a similar world, which gives great credibility to the story.The special effects are good, especially the design of the old and new robots. Robot Sunny, one of the main characters of the movie, is indebted to Alan Tudyk's voice and facial expression for making it believable and so unique.Will Smith brings great energy to the film, which make the action so enjoyable. Moreover, he worked hard to get his body in shape to appear in his underwear - unnecessary and hedonistic, but still very enjoyable.The action part is extremely entertaining and dynamic, so very engaging for the viewer. Not a moment of dullness or bore bits.The Bad Will Smith and Bridget Moynahan don't have much chemistry, and none of them, nor most of the supporting actors, shines for his acting in this movie. That wouldn't matter if the script was good and the dialogs decent, which is not the case.There are too many stereotypes in the characters of the movie, and in the robotics part, with many ideas copycatted from old classic Sci-fi films. There is no depth in the story in regards with 1/ what makes robots develop human-like behavior despite/thanks to their programming, and what makes them to be sociological oriented, and 2/ what makes us humans and our society so unique, and inimitable 3/ what is the limit between androids and humans.The persecutions against Will Smith are impossible to believe, he being attached massively and surviving everything that is thrown and done to him. That's fun, but that doesn't help a movie that already has many flaws.I confess, I tremendously enjoyed the movie, and I had a great time, but the movie is mediocre and does not offer anything new and fresh to the genre. If you are an Assimov fan, or you are looking for robot metaphysics, you'll be disappointed.

title: Loving it
content: I thought this movie was surprisingly very well made....actually really well made. The whole action, robots, the script, CGI and the cast were absolutely amazing. Will Smith did an amazing job even though there were some jokes which weren't laugh out loud types but it's actually a very serious meaningful film not some other silly trashy action movies that are plot less that you see these days. The script is very well made and the robots?....well what can I say, they are absolutely well made. Yup they may look like at first glance not very interesting but when the plot develops on the main robot Sonny you absolutely do feel for the robot and they begin to look very interesting. There is a quite lot of action which is pretty well made and yes there is a lot of CGI used but believe me...once you seen this movie you'll see how well the CGI is used and how it should be used in future films.If you like Will Smith, strong meaningful scripts, robots and action then this movie is worth your while.PS. there is a one very funny part by Will that made the whole audience laugh non stop for 5 minutes...I won't spoil it for you but it's the part where Will sneezes and says something very funny :)9.5/10 - GO SEE IT.

title: Exactly what you'd expect from a Smith cummer blockbuster
content: An entertaining film, full of explosions, minor plot twists and little character development. Worth seeing for the special effects and the story isn't too bad. There are a great many worse films than this around so I can safely recommend seeing this.Just don't expect to be too surprised by anything in this film. It's definitely run of the mill. The cast all perform well enough, Will Smith especially doing his usual act.The special effects are predictably the most impressive thing, the robots are stunning to look at, but again isn't that normal these days? I for one would be disappointed by anything less in a big budget Hollywood blockbuster.

title: Tired Pastiche of Sci Fi Clichés
content: I was thinking that the target audience for "I, Robot" was 12-year-old boys who have not read the original science fiction by Isaac Asimov that posited The 3 Laws or seen any science fiction movies, but surely even they have seen at least a "Matrix" or a "Terminator" movie where machines take over so that what are supposed to be climactic scenes here of robot revolution are just been-there-seen-that.Will Smith and some interesting dialog about robot-prejudice, that I'm willing to bet was inserted by the usually serious Academy Award-winning writer Akiva Goldsman, save the movie from seeming like a total pastiche of other movies.It is a bit much just how much music video director Alex Proyas uses the post-"Ali" Smith as pin-up fodder (maybe this is supposed to be the motivation for women ticket buyers?), let alone product endorser - he actually points out a pair of Converse sneakers several times to the camera, though the "Wall Street Journal" claims that a promotional fee was not paid.It's also a continuing hypocrisy in the ratings system that Smith gets to utter many "sh*t"s in a PG-13 movie while Fahrenheit 9/11 got an "R," let alone the indie movies that have to carry "NC-17."Bridget Moynahan does herself no favor in appearing opposite a robot with a soul, as Alan Tudyk's "Sonny" out acts her throughout the movie. While I suppose the target audience isn't looking at her acting abilities, would that the director had considered the minds of other potential fannies in the seats.(originally written 7/28/2004)

title: Worth a look *** out of ****
content: With the summer thrills at the theater slowly winding down, I Robot is certainly not the most refreshing sci-fi I've seen lately (like Minority Report) but it does succeed on a lot of levels.Will Smith is Del Spooner, a dedicated police officer who's assignments are homicide. Del is likable, smart and caring, unlike the idiot police officer he played in the horrible Bad Boys and the even dumber sequel.The year is 2035 and robots are the key to the nations economy. Virtually all tasks large and small are done with robots with three rules that cannot be broken.1.A robot must not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to be harmed.2.A robot must obey orders givin it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict with the first law.3.A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law.For reasons unknown, (well for the first 45 minutes) Spooner is the only one that doesn't trust them. (A clue is given at the very beginning but is not revealed until later.) When called to the scene of an apparent suicide by the creator of robots, (Dr. Alfred Lanning) Del is unsurprisingly convinced that it may be murder by the head robot Sonny. Though Smith is given top billing, Sonny pulls a Tommy Lee Jones (his character Gerard in The Fugitive) and slyly steals the rest of the show.The action rarely lets up and really gets going within the last 30 minutes and especially when the robots go completely beserk (caused by the one you don't expect) and director Alex Proyas who gave us The Crow and the vastly underrated Dark City has done a decent job of giving us what Steven Spielberg brilliantly did in Minority Report; good characters, good effects and the story, convincing.P.S. I'm sorry Mr. Roger Ebert but 52 million just proved you were wrong again. (see his review of this film and Scooby Doo)

title: I, Robot
content: Let's start with the obvious: The movie was "Suggested by Asimov."
