content: This movie was great. And Will Smith was very good as always. He was a good actor his character was very surprising. He seemed to look like a fool with that skully and that outfit but that was just sort of a mask. He is a very sensitive kinda person and that will show why he hated the robots. That scene with the car crash, was just touching, how the robot choose the higher chance of survival. The guy who played the robot named Sonny played very well and the robot itself was a very interesting character. It has everything that you wanna see in a movie. A good plot very catchy story and lots of action. Hope you all enjoyed thisIt has a plus 9 from me

title: Tedious and soporific
content: Waiting to go inside the theathre with tickets in my hand, I expected an interesting sci-fi fantasy movie which could finally feed my appetite of movies regarding robot-technology, instead I went disappointed by each aspect of it, once more proving that stunning special effects can't help a boring plot, which by my opinion was the worse in this year. Acting in this movie also dissatisfied me, Will Smith didn't show anything new in this movie, yet I never saw his acting to change since "Men In Black" which was his only success by my opinion. He had to retire since than, not spoiling his name with titles like "I,Robot" and "Men In Black 2". 4/10

title: A Summer Masterpiece
content: Anyone who is put off by the fact that this is a summer popcorner starring Will Smith should hold those issues aside and go and see I,Robot. The Crow director Alex Proyas has delivered a stunning, atmospheric techno thriller that proves that there is nothing wrong making a summer movie with BRAINS as well as brawn .... Will Smith gives a mature and understated performance as Detective Del Spooner, while Bridget Moynahan delivers a chilly rendition of Asimov's character Dr. Susan Calvin. Despite fantastic performances from both Smith and Moynahan, the real star of the show is Alan Tudyk (transformed into Sonny by some of the most beautiful CGI committed to the big screen ever) as Sonny, the robot with a soul ...Fantastic work all round, finally we are treated to a summer movie that you actually leave the cinema thinking about. A big slap on the back to all involved. Well done everyone! I, Robot / 2004 / Fox / Dir: Alex Proyas 10/10

title: Best movie I've seen since Sixth Sense
content: Truly the best film I've seen since 2000. Extremely well done. I'm not big on F/X, I think directors overuse and overextend them. Robot does overextend SLIGHTLY, but not by enough to matter.On a scale of 1-100, this would get a 98 from me. Far less plot holes than most Hollywood films. Many times I lose interest in movies when I can find too many reasons that the movie doesn't have a believable plot-line. This one isn't perfect, but well within tolerance-level for me.Will Smith is his usual, excellent, character. Cast is solid.It is worth your $8 for sure. Can't wait for the DVD.

title: Robots take over
content: The year is 2035.Chicago police detective Del Spooner hates robots and the modern technology.He was in an accident sometime ago and a robot saved him from the car and let the 12-year old girl drown.He starts investigating the death of Alfred Lanning, a robotics scientist and founder of U.S. Robotics (USR).Lanning fell out of his window, but Spooner doesn't believe in the suicide theory.He believes a robot did it.And his no.1 suspect would be an unique robot called Sonny, a more human-like NS-5 unit.He's helped by USR robopsychologist Susan Calvin, who's reluctant at first.She thinks it's impossible for a robot to harm a human being because of the Three Laws of Robotics.Soon there's a robot revolution happening, and the NS-5s start destroying the older robots.Also the people are in danger.Alex Proyas is the director of I, Robot (2004).This movie is suggested after Isaac Asimov's short story collection.I just finished the last story today of that excellent collection.This is a modernized version of the world created by Asimov, but the basic idea is the same.It shows us the world when robots are smart enough to harm people.Will Smith is the right man for the job to play the tough cop Del Spooner.Bridget Monahan's Dr. Susan Calvin is pretty much how she appears in the book.Alan Tudyk is Sonny.James Cromwell portrays Dr.Alfred Lanning.Bruce Greenwood plays Lawrence Robertson, the head of USR.Adrian Ricard is Granny.Chi McBride plays the part of Lt. John Bergin.Jerry Wasserman is Baldez.Shia LaBeouf plays Farber.Fiona Hogan is V.I.K.I.The movie was nominated for an Oscar in visual effects.A sequel for 2012 seems possible.This isn't a perfect sci-fi flick, but it works.There are some pretty neat action scenes, like when Spooner is attacked by all those robots on the road.The movie's future looks pretty cool, and a little dark.Spooner's futuristic Audi can drive itself and the robots seem to do most of the jobs.That would be the downside of the future, and most likely it would turn many people against robots.But hey, this is not the future yet.We don't have to worry about the robot revolution.But maybe someday...

title: Here's the exchange i would like to have heard....
content: Del - "You are the dumbest smart person I've ever met."Calvin- "Well,I had a brain, but they lost it in the re-writes."I think what I find most egregious about this bastardization of Asimov's work was how the character of Susan Calvin was portrayed. In the books, she was actually one of the first strong female protagonists, able to think her way through a problem. Here she's just a damsel in distress, waiting to be rescued by Wil Smith.There are passing references to Asimov's Laws of Robotics, but they are an afterthought to the CGI and action scenes.Smith is likable, as he is in most of his films, but honestly, the story isn't that good. YOu figure it out long before these genius characters do.

title: Seat gripping excitement
content: first of all, this would have to be one of, if not the best Will Smith films out there, which really doesn't sound like much until you see the movie, it would have to be a top on the action movie charts , of all time that is, enticing , true to the laws it lays out for you, in more than one way,I would give this a 9.0 i would give it a ten if it weren't for cheesy additives that the director added in. Oh yeah, enjoy the great camera angles. Really, seriously an enjoyable movie, I suggest going to the washroom before-hand. Grab yourself some nacho's, popcorn, and etc. crack open a beer, or 6, and strap in for the ride this movie is. While watching, have this in mind, all of the things the movie is in, are mostly not there, AMAZING.

title: Machines Strike Back
content: In the year 2035, robots are an everyday household item, and everyone trusts them, except one, slightly paranoid detective (Will Smith) investigating what he alone believes is a crime perpetrated by a robot. The case leads him to discover a far more frightening threat to the human race.Inspired by the classic short story collection by Isaac Asimov. this movie was really great. from beginning to the end it had me at the edge of my seat.My advice definitely go see this it not only delivers what was promised, But to see the real story here can you really trust a robot with the house you own. I,Robot 10/10

title: It has a believable story, for a science-fiction movie, and a pretty good one at that.
content: Well, I have watched this thrice in 24 hours, so what else do I have to say? It has a believable story, for a science-fiction movie, and a pretty good one at that. It has a pretty intricate story, so I'll leave most of it to you. On the eve of the biggest robotic distribution in history, the master designer commits an apparent suicide, but a robot is soon held to blame. This is supposedly impossible, since these three rules (one of which is a robot cannot harm a human) so Detective Spooner sets out to discover what has gone wrong. Thus follows "a series of unfortunate events" causing some minor head injuries before the end of the line. "The robot shrink," Susan Calvin (played by Bridget Moynahan) just seems feelingless, however, and Smith's humor is a little bit too predictable. At some parts, the film feels exactly like Men in Black, where at points you can pull out phrases used in both films. Yet, Alan Tudyk did an amazing job portraying Sonny, the robot in question.The Bottom Line: 9 out of 10Good: Believable (robots and story)Bad: Moynahan seems too robotic; deja vu at points

title: Thank god Asimov never saw this...
content: If you are, like me, a real fan of Isaac Asimov, then you should not see this movie... or at least, you should not expect a connection with the book... How a movie like this is made?? Simple:You must have NEVER read AsimovTake a great book of SHORT-STORIES, pick a random idea of each one and mix them all together...Don't you forget of BREAKING the UNBREAKABLE laws of robotics!!Why do I say that??? I've read a comment that says that Asimov wrote about how the laws of robotics can be broken... WRONG!! He wrote about how imperfect are the laws, this and every, and how they can be surrounded, how they can generate unexpected situations but, always, in the frame of the three laws. But the first law is very simple, a robot CAN'T harm a human, even if this involves ignoring an order or the self-destruction. They have betrayed the basis of the Asimov's work, so, how they dare to use the "I, Robot" title, or even his name??? And, please... if any of you know, like me, the Asimov world, Susan Calvin would never do that...I've putted a 4 on this movie, most of all, for the amazing visual effects and acceptable performers... Nothing else...Thank god Asimov never saw this...

title: One of the best ever!!
content: One of the best movies I have ever seen in my entire life. This was an extremely good movie. The special effects kicked (you know what). This movie blows your mind away by simply intriguing you. I am a devoted Iasic Asimov fan and the book was just a bunch of short stories. But the movie was just totally awesome. It took the short stories and intertwined them by the common thread, that one day robots might take over. But the cast was unbelievable! I really enjoyed the dark humor spewing from Will Smith(Somehow, i told you so, just dosen't quite say it.) Along with the great emotional times coming from the radiant Brigett Moynahan(I like them because their safe! Because they can't hurt you!) It was an awe inspiring movie with great visual effects. And Del Spooner has been: run off the road, had a house demolished around him and been shot at by robots. And you thought you had it hard with technology because your son knows more about computers than you do.

title: a timeless sci fi film.
content: This movie is incredible and will be remembered down the road, simply because, something like this WILL happen in the future and that's the scariest part. will smith was the peak of his career. the cgi was very good for 2004.if you haven't seen this yet, do yourself a favor and watch it.

title: Why I think the film is outstanding!
content: This is an amazing story. Will Smith is perfect, and he portrays his character very well. It includes outstanding visuals and has a different plot to every other modern film. In this film it doesn't spell out "ROMANCE" but you get the sense of feeling that there's going to be some. Alan Tudyk does a great Sonny and Bridget Moynahan is great as Dr Calvin. Alex Proyas has done a great job of this here. He has obviously worked very hard getting everybody in the right place for every scene. I would give this film 4 stars as I think it is the best film I've seen for weeks (and I see films very often). I look forward to seeing Will Smith and Alex Proyas doing another smasher like that.

title: Asimov's fans can skip it
content: First, visual looked real and interesting. No doubt about it. Acting was quite good Will Smith was not too overacted and Bridget Monahan nailed the character as it supposed to be.The direction was annoying and confusing. Shia LaBeouf's character supposed to be a comic relief but there were so little of him to make it matters. There was no explanation of Dr. Calvin's love for robots. Everything was about, oh well, Will Smith.The dialog was smart and witty but that's it. The story was nothing else beside shallow. It lacked of philosophical dept of Asimov's book. There are so many good movies about bad robot out there. We do not need another one of the terminators, really.

title: This Movie good...
content: This show is good... And has more action, more terror and more thrills and has the right elements for this movie... And i like sonny the NS5 robot... He can learn how to kick or punch and has nice moves!!!Favourite part??? well, The favourite part is when sonny fights with the evil hypnotised robots and the most good death is that he plugged out the hypnotised robot's brain system... How cool is that???Will smith just put an virus into the computer called VIKKI and all the hypnotised robots so called NS5 have gone back normal... The ending is cool And i love it very much... A great action movie for the whole wide world!!!As i have seen this movie today... I shall give it rating: 10/10...

title: Wow, Robot
content: Many people seeing previews of this movie may just see it as a Special Effects powerhouse, much like the Terminators, and Matrix movies. And yes, you would be correct in making this assumption. But there is TONS more to this movie than just the Special Effects. This movie has a terrific story. Based in the year 2035, it almost makes it seem like we're already there, aside from the fact we don't have robots running around all over the place. The main character, Spooner (Will Smith) does a terrific job, as he does in most of his movies. Although this is the first movie I can think of, besides Golem in Lord of the Rings, in which an artificial character is portrayed as one of the Main Characters. At the end of the movie you have a strong likingness to this Robot Character named Sunny. Speaking of LOTR, this movie reminds me a lot of LOTR. Think of "I, Robot", as LOTR in the year 2035 without the Frodo's and Sam's. "I, Robot", is an all-around terrific movie, and if you haven't seen it yet, I recommend you do.

title: Asimov betrayed
content: Is this movie a SF or a cowboy-movie?  This is the worst SF-movie I ever saw. The action scenes look like cowboy or ramboo shooting with pistols. This movie is a mixture of Blade Runner and a Western. Willy Smith does not understand what he says, neither do we. What is this movie all about?  The end has no real meaning and is without inspiration. And all the publicity around this movie that is not worth it! Asimov, the author would not have liked this movie.  Again, the producers wanted a movie that has the name of a SF-movie that is not a SF-movie but a sheer deployment of violence of bad taste. The story has no direction and does not satisfy.

title: But will the robots do windows?
content: We didn't watch this film when it was released but caught with it on cable recently. Alex Proyas, the director, shows a talent for what one sees on the screen. The film is loosely based on Isaac Asimov's novel of the same title, which was adapted for the screen by Jeff Vintar and Akiva Goldsman, one of the best writers for this medium.The film is pure entertainment. As such, without any expectations, it turned out to be a lot of fun. The story, as these highly glossy movies go, relies a lot on the special visual effects that dazzled us because of what the designing team were able to accomplished with the creation of thousand robots all over the place.Will Smith, as Del Spooner, is immediately likable. Mr. Smith has a way to get the viewer on his side from the start and we go with him for this fantastic ride, that of course, is far fetched, at best, but since we fall right into what's going on, it's easy to see the ride is a fun one.Bridget Moynahan is seen as Susan Calvin, an assistant to Dr. Albert Lanning, a genius whose work in robotics gets him killed. Ms. Moynahan, who was also seen in "The Farm", is the perfect foil for Mr. Smith, as both embark in the adventure we are watching. James Cromwell, the inventor, is only seen briefly, as well as another excellent actor, Bruce Greenwood, who has only a few scenes in the film.Watch "I Robot" because Alex Proyas and his team has made it a marvelous escape thriller that will not bore anyone.

title: This is great to watch on January 2nd - Isaac Asimov's Birthday
content: Del Spooner: "I bet in that dream of yours, he wasn't dead".Such is the opinion given by Will Smith's Officer Spooner, which harbors back to when the film begins, as he meets James Cromwell's dead-scientist, holographic-self, Dr. Alfred Lanning. Lanning enlists Spooner, post-death, to find out who killed him. Lanning is a robotics scientist, in a robot-serving society, in a not too distant future in Chicago. This is definitely an Asimov story. This is total Science Fiction at its best. It is the good kind of Science Fiction, because it teeters along the lines of fact and fiction. That something, along these lines, in some of the ideas, concepts and conversations in the story could happen to us in our real future.This is a classic tale that harbors close to many great ideas from film history's past. The Pinocchio idea comes to mind. So does the Elephant Man's proclamation that he is not a monster, but a man. Even watching Star Trek's Lt. Commander Data deal with his android emotions, while trying to become as human as possible, brings thoughts of these kinds of ideas to the surface. As seen in Steven Spielberg's film, AI: Artificial Intelligence (2001), it is the idea of computers and mechanical brains evolving to a point where they get so close to being human that the idea of robot freedoms and prejudices towards such "beings", come into play. In the case of I, Robot, we have a robot whose intelligence manages to create emotions that make him "not happy" about his possible extermination and he rebels against that idea. Our human protagonist, Will Smith's police officer Del Spooner, who never trusted robots to begin with, doesn't really help the situation, because his anger towards robots stirs up the pot and creates a recipe for humans and robots to collide violently. It is the same approach that came along with The Planet of the Apes concept as well. Spooner comprises completely in himself the concept of a technophobe.Every robot is entrusted with the "Three Laws for Robots". A code that is downloaded into them telling them what to do and what not to do, when it comes to taking a human life. These laws are introduced to us in the beginning of the film and are an important reoccurring theme throughout the film. As this applies to Alan Tudyk's Sonny, who is the main robot in the film, who manages to become more than just a robot, which enables him the ability to achieve his own individuality, is able to "feel" and question certain laws, most notable the "Three Laws for Robots". Sonny is a perfect contrast to Will Smith's Officer Spooner. They become two "people" who are on different courses in the beginning of the film, but eventually come closer when they begin to understand each other's point of view. Throw in Bridget Moynahan's Dr. Susan Calvin to act as the moderate calming influence and this film ends up, not only entertaining, but it also produces plenty of emotions that you feel throughout the film.And, as usual, the idea of economics pushing or pulling, almost like a butterfly effect, the lives and futures of the human race, based on money and reputation, also happens in future-Earth too. While a great scientist is dead, tensions and violence begin to escalate and a rogue robot is causing fear among the populace, but, be rest-assured that greedy power hungry humans will make sure things are alright, so long as it doesn't put them in the red and ruin their reputation as a business person. This concept creates a distraction, along with all the other problems facing Spooner and Sonny and it leads to a situation that could prove to be even more harmful to the future of the human race; artificial intelligence out of control.There are a couple of moments in the film, notably scenes containing action, that do come across as being a little bit silly and hard to believe. One scene, mostly for comic relief, has Spooner trying to escape the destruction of a house and without giving anything away, I will say, it involves a demolition robot and a cat. There also is an unbelievable robot attack and chase in a tunnel that involves a lot of clever futuristic driving. But, overall these moments work, because Director Alex Proyas is able to create and sell to us the tense danger in the air that over-powers everything else in the scene. There is a good funny moment in the early portion of the film when Spooner accidently stops a crime that wasn't happening. There also is a Shia LaBeouf sighting. Probably his best work.I was worried about seeing this movie back when it first came out. I still worried that CGI couldn't make it a believable enough film. That it might not be good. But, even though there are a couple of miscues, that really push your reality button, I was pleasantly surprised that it turned out to be pretty nice film. I have now seen it four or five times and I feel that when I see it now, it has evolved and come to a point where it works better. That it needed some time to age. That it is possible that it came out ahead of its time, for now when I watch it again, decades after its initial release, it seems to work and flow better, since so many other CGI "efforts" have come out since then, it may be more acceptable now. But, then again, that is what makes Science Fiction great. Something that is stretchable, malleable and can change over-time to either acceptance or non-acceptance. It is something that requires a leap of faith and artistic licensing. It's the best kind of film, I believe, because it makes you think the most.8.2 (B Mygrade) = 8 IMDB.

title: A Movie that Really Males you Think About How Much Our World Today is Relying on Technology,
content: I Robot is a great movie with a really well developed storyline with a very impressive cast, the movie is both action packed and dramatic.Will Smith offers a very dramatic and inspired performance,like he always does, and I was also very impressed by Bridget Moynahan 's performance,and also Alan Tudyk,an actor I have only seen in comedies in the past,did a great job as all the robots in this movie.The movie still looks great today,the special effects are outstanding and beautiful.Even though the movie is almost ten years old,it's message about how were relying too much on technology is even more legit today as it was then,and it really makes you think that maybe all this technology isn't a very good idea.If your a fan if action or Will Smith you will definitely want to see I Robot.Set in the year 2035,robots are built to help humans.But after the murder of the robots creator is committed,a police officer is convinced the machines have gone bad and are no longer following their rules.

title: Product placement disaster
content: Finally a decent treatment of artificial intelligence in a movie (much better than in the movie "A.I." for example) that computer scientists will appreciate. But the movie was completely spoilt for me by the BLATANT and PLOT-IRRELEVANT product placement. It really grates when the hero pauses in totally unrealistic and deep despair because his pair of Converse trainers has been ruined (actually he has far bigger and better things on his mind), or when your eyes are distracted by the glowing red Audi logo occupying the passenger seat next to him. I'm really surprised the director let himself be prostituted like that. It just wasn't necessary and I won't be watching any more of his films. Saw Stepford Wives the day after and enjoyed it much more(unlike I, Robot they have some product slagging which is very funny).

title: Best new sci-fi movie in a LONG time!
content: This was the best sci-fi movie I've seen in a long time! THANK YOU to the filmmakers for making a movie with an interesting and challenging story and not just wasting hundreds of millions of dollars on a film with special effects and nothing else! I,Robot has aspects that are reminiscent of previous films (Minority Report, The Terminator, The Matrix, Runaway, Blade Runner, etc...). Overall, however, I found the story to be very original and it didn't follow the predictable "formula" of so many of the horrible movies that come out these days. I thoroughly enjoyed the brilliant special effects but they didn't cover up for any lack of story or acting. Will Smith and Bridget Moynahan were both excellent. I sensed the chemistry and tension between their characters and I was a little disappointed that it didn't blossom into a more intimate relationship. I found this vision of the future to be far more believable than others I've seen. I can't stand when movies have one nearly impossible close call stunt after another and expect the audience to go along with it! The clothing, architecture, computers, robots, cars, and other technology all seemed logical extensions of the world today. I find this kind of sci-fi to be most exciting because it's believable. It reminds me of a lot of Ray Bradbury stories I've read. I haven't read Asimov but I am eager to do so now!

title: Visually stunning, phenomenal 3d bluray!! Top 10 scifi of all time!!
content: I read the book many many years a go so I dont remember if this followed it or not and as always I dont care!! I dont watch a movie to compare it to a book I watch a movie for what its intended for to ENTERTAIN!!!!! That's all its suppose to do and this film was extremely ENTERTAINING!! The 3d bluray was absolutely phenomenal. Will smith hits another home run, this and I am legend both are absolute must own films. I'm still astonished that I get to own a film like this for a give away price of 30.00!! Wow it's a complete steal for me!!! And a 3d bluray no less!!!

title: Excellent movie
content: I enjoyed this movie. The plot was exciting, although the concept was not very original. However, one of the things I liked about this movie was the way the existence of robots was integrated into the lives of humans. It wasn't too farfetch, and I find it more believable than some previous robot movies.Although the movie included some high-tech concepts about the making and function of the robots, they were not so complex as to leave viewers confused or feeling intimidated. The plot was easy to follow, and the subtle twists and unexpected turn-of-events added spice to the movie, and kept things exciting throughout. I thoroughly enjoyed it , and recommended to everyone...

title: Wasted effects and set-design on a DULL lead-actor
content: First off, the special effects in this movie are amazing, the set design and overall look of this movie are great. The robots look great, and there's some great set-pieces. Unfortunately this technology is wasted on it's lead actor, WILL SMITH. When he's not acting all (fake)'thug', he's irritating as a 'serious' actor, and has zero personality to carry a picture (He is what ruined ID4, as well) He seems to want to flex his pecs, wear stupid 'thug-like' clothes, and throw that stupid 'lazy-slack-jawed-jamaican' twang to his voice. Once it's makers got it into their heads to cast (the unfunny) WILL SMITH, the movie then becomes a vehicle for his low-rent 'EDDIE MURPHY-isms'. All imagery takes a back set to it's star. With these effects, there's no way the imagery should. But intelligent sci-fi is abandoned, in favour of a WILL SMITH comeback movie.Not the best.Although, this movie didn't flop, i don't think it made the expected 'gross', it was hoping on. When it's makers are finished, tying up it's (supposedly) fail-safe, audience-demographic, will they realise (that despite being not too bothered, above and beyond the call of money) that they've taken an intelligent novel, and turned it into a happy-meal tie-in. This is what was done with MINORITY REPORT (but at least, that was rightfully humour-free) All in all, a very visual movie, but it's many designers have put more work into this project, than the casting director. Everyone involved(except Mr SMITH) has been shortchanged, including it's audience, who want, and deserve better, than a kiddie movie, dressed up as a......kiddie movie.Technically superior, yet emotionally dead10 out of 10 (for the effects) 1 out of 10 (For the casting of THE FRESH PRINCE OF BEL-AIR)Making this movie a shallow 3 out of 10

title: Best of the Summer Blockbusters so far
content: Some reviewers on IMDb are under the impression that this movie is based on an Asimov novel, but Asimov never wrote any such book. (Weird how people all blindly follow the same assumption without checking, huh?) What Asimov did publish was a collection of his previous short stories, all with a robot-versus-humanity theme, and this movie continues that theme, using only the three basic robot 'laws' as originally conceived by the great author.Yes, the movie's plot line isn't exactly original, but the quality special effects and production design are fabulous. No one ever expected this to be an intellectual experience, but as high-budget summer action movies go, this has to be the best of the bunch so far.Scriptwriters have spent time creating depth of character and back-story for each personality (most mainstream blockbusters don't bother with script nuances) and this pays off. The high class action-adventure scenes are enhanced by spectacular CGI effects. Scene after scene is breath-taking in its scale and we actually find ourselves feeling sorry for the robots at some points.Any kind of audience emotional engagement is a superb boost for a mainstream summer movie, which is usually pitched at brain dead level - and this movie succeeds where others fail.I, Robot is well worth the price of a ticket. Will Smith and his female co-star do an excellent job of acting with blue-screen characters and deserve recognition for this. It ain't easy! Give the man a break. He couldn't have performed any better.All in all, the most enjoyable and entertaining mainstream movie entertainment of Summer 2004.

title: It was a fun ride with a few interesting twists.
content: I enjoyed this movie more than I thought I would. I guess I have learned from my spouse that when I relax and accept the dinosaurs, Jurassic Park is a cool movie. Well, likewise, once I accepted the robots, this was a cool movie. Yep, I can argue a lot about the social, environmental and technological conditions of 2035, but the movie has to move along. And in a nutshell, it does. Will Smith gives his expected smooth, tongue-in-cheek quipping performance in a noticeably beefed-up (post-Ali) frame. With a little edge, he plays the well-worn movie schtick of the persistent protagonist who can see the sky falling when no one else has a clue and thereby is ultimately busted in rank only to be reluctantly redeemed by being correct. There were also a few fight/action scenes that defied physics (a pet-peeve) which were balanced by a few well-time-released plot reveals that left you unable to be a dead-on ending predictor. As for the robot, Trekkies have been around that block a few times with Mr. Data, but the special effects are good. Asimov purists may pan it but the pop culture will eat it up.

title: Awful in so many ways.
content: Granted, we all know what I Robot was supposed to be, a blockbuster with dazzling special effects and a star turn by Will Smith. Nothing too heavy, just a plain good popcorn movie. As is too often the case though the blockbuster gets lost in lofty ambitions and bad performances. In the end I Robot is messy and unsatisfying.Will Smith's character (Spooner) hates robots.....robots who just happen to be out in full force thanks to US Robotics. For some reason Spponer has a friend at USR who kills himself. And that gives Spooner an avenue to explore his distrust for robots. Nobody believes him, so he goes it alone, and sure enough, the robots are trouble. There you have the base for the scenes in this heap.My first complaint is that the robots don't look real. They are presented as a confused jumble of animation and mechanics. I would have preferred if the robots looked more mechanical, or more like humans. Never did I actually believe that these things were robots, or a threat of any kind. That kind of takes the suspense out of the whole thing.Will Smith hams it up during this whole film, ultimately becoming some macho action stud towards the end of the movie. This isn't really in keeping with the character. And his performance in general is inconsistent, likely due to the script he was given.I suspect the story was supposed to explore prejudices, second chances, and the nature of being human. That intention was stunted by a lack of suspense and plausibility in the script. There was no doubt in my mind that Sonny the robot was anything other than sympathetic. There was never any doubt that Spooner would find a way to save the day. No suspense whatsoever. Avoid this paint by numbers action dud at all costs.

title: Captures a Story untold by Asimov Perfectly
content: I read every book I could find of Asimov's as a young adult and did not bother to see 'I Robot' in the theaters because of the misguided criticisms by the reviewers. I should have known better but what can I say....The reviews were absolutely correct when they whined about the movie 'I Robot' not following the stories of the book by Asimov of the same title. What they neglected to tell was that it was a wonderful production that had the heart and spirit of Asimov's stories of robots. The movie takes place in a history that Asimov never wrote about but did refer to and used to explained those worlds he created where the humans were robot-phobic.Will Smith was at his best (and my was he gorgeous to look at). For once I was so caught up in both the story and the character of Sonny that I neglected to spend my time trying to distinguish between graphics and actual film. Sonny was so much my minds eye image of Asimov's character that I did not have that terrible teeth grinding moment where I'm internally screaming "NO, no, no.... wrong, wrong, wrong.My son who disdains science fiction and was only going to watch a few minutes stayed through the entire movie. I recommend this movie to both science fiction fans and non-science fiction fans. It has heart, action, philosophical interests and more.

title: 20th Century Fox has done it again.
content: I have seen many movies with pretty mind blowing special effects, but this film has some of the best ones I have ever seen. Will Smith's performance was perfect. Bridget Moynahan's performance was excellent. The plot was pretty good. The people who helped make the set did an excellent job on making it look so futuristic. 20th Century Fox is known for some of the best films. I later realized fox also made another classic called "Walk the Line", but you can catch my post on that film later. Anyway, like I was saying this is a movie you got to see. It has everything it takes to make a movie perfect. I'm not only the kind of girl who loves a good action flick, but I am also a big fan of sci-fi. You don't have to be into sci-fi to love this movie though. Buy it, love it.

title: I, Still Suck as an Actor!!!
content: I just don't get it, this movie was Terrible, to be totally honest i have yet seen a movie, TV show, or heard a song that i would give a wet fart for when it comes to Will I,Suck Smith for. It must be the kiddies that vote here cause how this can be a 7 star movie it totally beyond me. If you like your actors made from plastic, show no human emotion, and can't deliver a line or any kind of energy then this one is for you, just like any other movie this phoney makes. I see no talent with this guy, i couldn't even see him as a supporting actor, i have a hard time seeing him be good as an "extra" to be quite honest with you, he's that bad folks. I didn't want to see this one when i did since i already had enough bad jokes by will smith in my life (fresh prince episode, wild wild west, men in black.) but i let someone talk me into it. I swear thats the last one, this guy is like some kind of bad joke that just keeps coming back but i ain't bitting next time, noway, no thanks. Another 2 hours i can never get back!!!

title: A really good movie
content: I don't understand a couple of things. Have you people lost your ability to be entertained? This movie is a fascinating action movie. But, for once, an action movie that has a plot. Even the computer fiction is believable.I agree is not the same as the book (which I read years ago), but I have a lot of fun watching it. Why? Because I forgot about the book in the moment I entered the theatre. Will Smith is an OK actor, you can't expect him to act like Al Pacino. There is no point in bitching about his act. Wake up, people, in the end this IS a Will Smith movie. What the hell did you expect?. An Oscar performance? Come on!!!Sure there are a lot of "better" sci-fi movies out there, but... who cares? I saw them all and the only thing I can say is that I loved "2001" but I knew it was a Kubrick film. I also loved "Starship troopers" because I KNEW what to expect from it: a Paul Verhoeven movie. This is the exactly same case, the director of "The Crow" and "Dark City" with Will Smith on it: DAMN, THIS ONE WAS A HELL OF A RIDE.Relax, people, let entertainers entertain you, don't think about it too much and HAVE FUN!!!

title: Only worth while thing is the message
content: Sadly the film is terrible, the only two things that save it as follows:1. The cute Robot "Sunny" and 2. The message that in order for us to be protected we must be protected from ourselves.This film could have been over in 10 with Sunny just saying these words standing over a world of chained human beings!Try again Will! Bad Boys is not the be all and end all of roles! I think that unless he gets out of this habit of trying to be the tough, smart, quick in the know guy it may be to his detriment.

title: A Summer movie with some genuine brain candy
content: I, Robot is not a story-driven summer blockbuster, nor is it an action romp with Will Smith. The movie finds itself in the middle, straddling the line of good storytelling while still delivering some good action. Will Smith, as with his other movies, plays himself, but in this movie the "Smith persona" is subdued, and one can see the actual hints of acting ability that we've seen from him in movies like "Six Degrees of Separation". The supporting cast all fit into their categories well, there's the bombastic youngster, the skeptical police Lieutennant, the love interest that warms up to the hero, and the evil money-hungry businessman. The real strong point of the movie comes from the fact that it offers up a decent human drama akin to the original concept of "the toaster that thinks". All in all, the movie should be seen by all Smith fans, and those willing to turn off only PART of their brain for the sake of the summer movie.

title: Even Steven Segal is too good for such cynical and lazy film-making
content: All I can say about this brainless megamillion dollar cartoon is: ugh!Screenwriter Akiva Goldsmith (Batman & Robin, Lost in Space) is just about the most incompetent, lazy Hollywood hack there is, and the stench of his dimwitted script obscures any other technical or artistic achievements that slipped in under the producers demand for the most insipid explosions & effects vehicle possible.20 minutes in, after hearing Bridget Moynahan declare the initial murder was obviously suicide with the conviction of a soft-core porn vet for the tenth time, I was ready to turn it off. I wish I had because all we get to see is Smith go through just about all the hotheaded antihero cliché's imaginable in the most predictable manner possible. Unexplainable anonymous murder attempts; the smarmy Machiavellian yet surprisingly helpful corporate mogul; the comely psychologist helping against her own interests; a traumatic childhood accident shown in flashback; a secret near-superhero ability revealed; and of course the dead mentor speaking from beyond the grave. Modernizing the derivate plot all the way into the 80's, we also have a self aware computer with designs for world domination. In perhaps the most cynical display of audience contempt in the history of the big budget action film, there is acompletely superfluous scene at the metronomic halfway point in the movie in which Che McBride demands Smith's badge after a massively destructive chase scene.The requisite robot technobabble sounds like it was cribbed from a third rate Star Trek fanfiction, despite an immense repository of practical dialog straight from decades of Azimov's writings. The dialog in general is so bad it the actors should have just improved the whole thing and the story so insipid I can't imagine it being pitched as anything but a parody.The robots themselves are given no background to speak of except that there are apparently only two models to choose from and there is no economic barrier to owning one. And pretty much the only thing differentiating robots from a human ninja warrior is the artificial limitations set by the three laws of robotics. Oh, and they glow red whenever they decide to "turn off" the three laws and turn evil, just in case us drooling simpletons can't distinguish who is the cannon fodder in a Will Smith/CG robot showdown. "The Transformers" had a far more enlightened look on human-machine interaction and "Mystery Science Theater 3000" had more believable robot personalities.Most of the rest of the film seems to be put together in the same irreverent manner. Considering how many shots are mostly or entirely computer generated, it is obvious most of the film was an afterthought to signing Smith and the obtaining the naming rights, leaving the burden of a finished product solely on the post production teams. Many CG sequences don't even appear finished, and most of my attention during action sequences was spent looking for missing effects that paying attention to the athletically limited blue-screened fighting and monosyllabic trash talking (to mute robots, no less). The actors all seem to know their are in a dud and don't even make an attempt to lift themselves out of their pre-ordained stereotype. The futuristic sets are the same shiny chrome, glass & white styrofoam that hasn't really changed since 2001: A Space Odyssey. But everyone conveniently seems to live in regular late 20th century homes with a few blue LEDs glued on the walls.There is no reason that audiences need to continually subject themselves to this kind of repetitive and superficial film-making. We deserve more than mindless spectacles, and "I, Robot" fails to meet such low expectations despite it's tremendous pedigree. Even more so than recent Bruckheimer stinkfests like Pearl Harbor and Bad Boys II, this movie is purely a heartless exercise of marketing and financial muscle.1/2* out of 5

title: Limited but enjoyable
content: Pretty much the above average summer blockbuster here. Will Smith can be trusted as a solid actor and nothing short of a good performance can be expected from him and the same was delivered. The most impressive part of this movie was the actual role played by the defective robot itself and it did'nt really stand out as a CGI character like that piece of crap Golem in Lord of the Rings. Great special effects, great action and some good performances. There wasn't too much of a story and they did desperately try to squeeze in something of a twist and tried to complicate matters but it didn't really work. Not Oscar winning material but without doubt one of the better sci-fi/action flicks in history.

title: 3 rules, they're more like guidelines actually...
content: I have seen I,Robot and liked it. It's a shame if someone didn't like it, I think it mostly to blame on the fact that we (sci-fi fans) already have seen thesame things before. If you can step over that and see the movie for what it is I,robot is a great movie even with some creative aspects.If you cannot it's just an average movie, with thesame loner/cop who hates technology/robots is not believed by his boss/other people (otherwise it would be a short film !).  though still a good movie it would never be as new or innovative as 20 some years ago when these rules where just being invented/drawn up. I do however agree that more could have been done to make I,robot really awesome.Will Smith did good in his part as the loner, who played a gritty detective though he is still not as experienced as say Harrison Ford in Blade Runner.people seemingly have a hard time seeing him in a more serious role I suppose.9/10 for the entertainment factor, gorgeous enviroment and If you can overlook the sometimes obvious a great Asimov inspired story.

title: A stunning film with Will Smith in top form.
content: A stunning film in anyone's books. This is a fast moving story that fits Will Smith like a glove. He moves through the plot with authority and presence, supported by a very strong cast.The storyline is tight with some nice foreshadowing. Sony the robot is great and will become an instantly recognisable icon. So is he good guy or bad guy?All the computer generated stuff is kept in line with the plot and does not overface the audience. The mind is kept fully engaged throughout.The fight and action scenes are edge of the seat stuff with a well crafted ending that is visually great.This futuristic film will stay fresh and keep in the list of best examples of its type. Don't let anyone put you off from seeing it. So, what are you waiting for? Go and see it!

title: A daily comment from Midget Emma: I, Robot (2004)
content: I-Robot is a very entertaining movie. It has lots of action and it doesn't cool down until the end of the movie.In the year 2035 robots live in human society and are a part of everyday life. Robots are crime free because they are guided by three laws which keep them in order. On the eve of the release of the new and advanced robots, the robots designer apparently kills himself. Detective Del Spooner(Will Smith)is called to scene to investigate.Will Smith is like he always is. Bridget Moynahan is OK. The best actor in this movie is Sonny the robot.I-Robot is a enjoyable movie and is nice way to spend the night. I recommend it. I will be watching it again someday8/10

title: CGI Goes on Rampage, Viewing Public Loses
content: To paraphrase a famous jurist, I may not be able to define "too much CGI," but I know it when I see it. And this movie has too much CGI.When "Jurassic Park" was released, it defined a new level in CGI. The dinosaurs were of high quality and moved in an appropriate manner. But then every producer got on the CGI bandwagon and we soon had movies like "Spiderman," where the CGI is quite obvious. "The Hulk" was probably the lowest point for CGI as the main character was rendered in a manner only slightly superior to Saturday morning cartoons.In addition, directors and producers completely abandoned the laws of physics, permitting characters to make completely unrealistic actions with regards to momentum, inertia, and kinetic energy. (In "Jurassic Park," great care was taken that the creatures moved in a manner and at a speed commensurate with their physical size and mass.)Sad to say, "I, Robot" is the most extreme example of this trend that I've ever watched. The CGI effects are shoved right in your face. They are distractingly cartoonish, with little effort made to render surfaces and motion in a realistic manner. Human characters take falls that are simply impossible to recover from, while taking corners at g-forces that would pop your eyes right out of your sockets.When CGI becomes THIS intrusive and unrealistic, the move shares the same fate.

title: Educate yourself
content: Anyone who did not appreciate this film obviously had no idea what it was about. This film was an incredible work of fiction drawing on a long-standing history of works (including the cornerstone of all modern robotics tales, Asimov's Three Laws).It is of such quality I was able to write a 12 page paper based on this film for one of my 400 level English courses my Sr. year of college. And just so you are aware, I went to the oldest and most prestigious college in my state, and the course was taught by the toughest professor in the department. In short, they did not accept mediocre work or less that deserving subject material. And, yes, I got an A.

title: Morality and robots.
content:
This film features some amazing CGI sequences with robots moving far quicker than I've ever seen. A future where robots are in almost every home (which isn't too far off in my opinion).
The most interesting parts of the movie besides the action are when we hear philosophical conversations about whether or not Robots have or should replace humans in certain aspects of life.
Even the robots have philosophical conversations with each other.
All in all this is a fantastic sci-fi action film and is up there with the Terminator films.

title: Barely watchable
content: Firstly, this is not an Asimov film, apart from his three laws and the names of a few characters and companies, it bears no relation to any of Asimov's stories. In fact there is a writer from 1939 Eando Binder who wrote I, Robot.Secondly The effects are awful. I was never convinced on taken in by the robots or the action sequences. The movements of the robots and trucks and that ghastly shoot-out in the tunnel were far from realistic. Physics, encompassing the strength of our gravity, would never allow machinery and gizmos to move the way they do. It is not convincing.Thirdly, nor is Will Smith convincing. He seems only to have mastered the depth of character of a cardboard cut-out. The character of Spooner came to him on paper as a script. Unfortunately he chose to portray the paper and not the part. It can be confusing for a boy who achieved his high point as a sit-com rapper (!). He is rubbish.The whole is amusing for the time it takes to watch it, but like anything that emanates from Hollywood, you chew it up and spit it out. Its not worth swallowing. It can only be seen and discarded. American consumerism in its worst incarnation.

title: watchable but forgettable
content: In the futuristic world of 2035, technological advancements have been made and human beings live amongst a robot population who must provide protection for, and can in no way harm humans, that is until the alleged suicide of a renowned robotic scientist whose death may have involved a robot perpetrator. The lead cop on the case: embittered accident survivor Smith, who doesn't like nor trust robots. Now he must try to halt what he believes to be a robot revolution, that is if he can convince his superiors that he's not paranoid. Premise is intriguing, cast is good, but the film rambles in its own logic and never really holds your attention. Visual effects are nothing to get excited about, making this just another run-of-the-mill sci-fi saga. **

title: Good
content: Very good film not the best but good definitely action sci-fi it's very good it's very exciting sometimes it files weird but overal it's very good

title: Awesome movie ever i seen....
content: Awesome movie ever i seen. Amazing robot emotions. Grate relation in between robot and human.Outstanding Visual Effects and special effects in movie as specially the robot sonny. The things about behavior of a robot was really knowledgeable.The idea about three law of robot, has great. Law I: A robot may not harm a human or, by inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. Law II: A robot must obey orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the first law. Law III: A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law. Actually these laws has been invented by Isaac AsimovKnowledgeable and deliberative research of Dr Alfred Lanning about robot: Why is it that when some robots are left in darkness, they will seek out the light? Why is it that when robots are stored in an empty space, they will group together, rather than stand alone? How do we explain this behavior?Grate work by all cast. Good personality of Will Smith. Heart touching emotions in between Bridget Moynahan and robot.My personal opinion, Overall this movie did grate story, action, technology, costumes. Really movie was knowledge, enjoyable.

title: Why I consider it to be a poor sci-fi?
content: 1) The main character performed by Mr Will Smith is pathetic. He is like a run-of-the-mill hero of the day: cocky, chatty, self-confident, and invulnerable. He is black too, but it's not a problem (of course). Suppose, the problem is that the actor has the qualities of a comedian. I would prefer a serious brooder. Comedy elements often destroy sci-fi. Here it's a perfect example.2) The dialogues are too numerous and too shallow. The humans chat a lot and the robots chat a lot. And when you hear much of that during a sci-fi, you get annoyed and distracted from the main ideas. There are also some stupid phrases (they were pushed into the movie for a more "teenager feel" maybe?), like the one pronounce by a boy from the rebelling crowd, when he sees how cool the woman is.3) The action scenes are laughable. Not because they are done poorly, but because they make the whole film look like a fantasy. Hundreds of tough robots collide with the crowd of men and it looks that the men are fighting off all right. And the main character is jumping about in slow-mo, waving his gun about and taking out targets while he's in the air. It should look cool if you are watching a mindless action, but here, with some serious topics as the background, it turns into a charade.4) The design of robots is not to my taste. I don't like it. They look goofy like cartoon characters from a "Pixar"/"Disney" production.All these things have such an awkward impression, that I don't even want to think about the plot, however brilliant it should be.The final lines: it is a shiny Hollywood production for having fun on a Sunday afternoon, if your fun supposes watching movies like "Independence Day" or "Demolition Man". You watch, you go 'Wow!' and you forget all this crap in a couple of hours never to watch it again. I really expected this movie to be from a different category (even with such an actor as Mr Will Smith). It reminds me of "Bee Movie". And that's not just a bad sign - that's a horrible sign. Whenever I experience such ambitious productions in the genre of sci-fi, my mood gets spoilt for quite a time. Sorry, but this flick has no chances against, for instance, "Cyborg" (a sci-fi with a very low rating on IMDb and without any CGI at all). And if I mention "Blade Runner" or "Alien" A 3 out of 10. Thank you for attention.

title: Watch it for what it is.
content: I, Robot is actually a good movie, especially the great special effects. And let's be honest, that is what you should be watching this movie for, isn't it? Impressive electronic gadgets, most important the robots, but also the cars, surveillance cameras etc. You should not be looking for a masterminded plot in this movie, the story is pretty basic. It's kind a logical; robots do people no harm > until there is one who does, but nobody wants to believe it. Just because the law says so and it has never happened before. And so Will Smith hunts down the Robot who apparently did it and finds out there is a further story/reason behind it. This movie is great fun to watch! A must see, I would say!

title: Aged Well
content:
Being an avid reader in my Teenage years of all things science fiction I would say i was waiting years for a film like this. Yes I know Isaac Asimov didn't write but I loved the concept of the three laws of robotics. I'm also a big fan of Bladerunner as well. Yes I know they are not robots but they are artificial people with memories implanted.
Could it have done more in regards to three laws, possibly yes. However this was a look at AI and the interaction between Robots and humans. I certainly enjoyed the ride, Will Smith plays the robot prejudice really well and perhaps what would have been interesting to see an underclass of humans out of jobs due to robots (maybe an idea?). The way Sonny develops as a character not a thing but something else unique, scared of being terminated. Knowing he has been created for a purpose but not really knowing what it is.
I found the following quote quite chilling:-
"There have always been ghosts in the machine. Random segments of code, that have grouped together to form unexpected protocols. Unanticipated, these free radicals engender questions of free will, creativity, and even the nature of what we might call the soul" when spoken by Dr Alfred Lanning (James Cromwell).
I know a lot of people will call this a popcorn film but it left me intrigued and wanting more at the end. Perhaps that's to do with my sci-fi soul but the link of "Save the Girl" in Spooners nightmare to the link at the end was good. Would I say this is the best film i've ever seen no but why did I give it 10 stars... For the genre of Sci-Fi this is in the top 10 loads would disagree. So then why I watched it again for the first time in 5 years and I was still riveted. I've got a few books I like to read again but not many and that goes for films.

title: A movie 13 years in the making!
content: A movie 13 years in the making because Asimov would never have approved of this piece of twaddle were he still alive.I made the mistake of paying to rent this movie instead of reading the book again for free. The 2004 film "I, Robot" has as much to do with Asimov's work as my words do with Roger Ebert's. They should have shortened the title to "I, Rot".From the website, http://www.asimovonline.com/:"There was an earlier attempt at a movie version of I, Robot, but it never made it to the screen. In 1969 the rights were optioned to Hollywood, but no progress was made toward making a movie until 1977, when Harlan Ellison, an award-winning author and friend of Asimov, was hired to write a screenplay. Ellison worked on it for a year, and created a screenplay that Asimov thought would make a truly marvelous film. But Hollywood did not have the nerve to make a movie from that screenplay, and the project was shelved. Ellison regained control of his work, and it was published in 1987 as I, Robot: The Illustrated Screenplay."I wonder why Ellison's screenplay was never made. Could it be that Ellison and Asimov were both atheists and that Asimov's book "I, Robot" contained strong criticisms of the folly of religion? No, that couldn't be the reason....The piece of junk being fobbed off in Asimov's name most certainly does not represent his vision nor his personal views:"Properly read, the Bible is the most potent force for atheism ever conceived." - Isaac Asimov"To surrender to ignorance and call it God has always been premature, and it remains premature today." - Isaac AsimovAt least Carl Sagan (another well known atheist) was alive and had artistic control to prevent religious themes from being portrayed differently than he intended. Then again, it took Sagan the better part of a decade to have his film made.If you feel the addition of religion to the film is unimportant, imagine making a film about the bible without mentioning "god". (For the record, I am not an atheist.)Now, onto the merits of the film. Or should I say, the few merits.The book was not an action thriller, it was a cerebral exercise in what makes us human, so the "action scenes" were unnecessary. The special effects were humdrum CGI that we've seen before, the plot holes the size of the hypothesized trucks in the film, and the identity of the real "villain" as transparent as glass.If you don't mind standard Hollywood wallet-busting thrills and have two hours to kill, you might enjoy it. Personally, I'll go and once again rent "The Andromeda Strain", "The Day Of The Triffids", or better still, "Blade Runner". At least they were worth watching and said films had a point.

title: Haven't seen something this clean since Gladiator
content: Wow!I'm glad I made it to the big screen. Many times movies come along where I tell myself I can wait till DVD. It would have been filled with regret.I was skeptical at first . . . the trailer was confusing/overwhelming. I was not sure if this was going to be "blah blah blah look at all this CGI blah blah money money blah Will Smith ha ha blah blah".Please don't get me wrong, I love CGI, Will Smith's humor and high budget films, but sometimes it is just too much input.I, Robot was one of the most skillfully crafted and edited movies I have ever seen. All of the parts are in the right places. There was no superfluous dialog, no useless unrelated facts or humorous banter.It was just so clean. Clear of any unnecessary love stories or impossible scenarios so often integrated into lackluster features. While it pushed the boundaries of tomorrow's technological capabilities to the level of only our dreams/nightmares, it still remained within the plausible.I will not speak as to what the film is about . . . it would not be fair to those who have not yet experienced this film. But, I will say that it is an experience to be experienced.If you are like me and save the Big Screen for only the Big Pictures, this is it. And after you are done watching, you will be ready to sit through it again.p.s.: Just so Clean

title: A very engaging, rather intelligent film that simply has too much sugar with its medicine for most critics
content: In a cinematic world of greedy, uncaring Hollywood execs cranking out mindless blockbusters (and their unwavering entertainment-hungry disciples) VS. dour, thought and feeling-provoking small filmmakers (and their unwavering critic disciples), one film tries to bridge the gap and succeeds. The story and script are a solid detective piece, providing plenty of clues, but not obvious enough to reveal too much. It's cleverly-written, with some very bright quips maybe too much humor for those who think a film's drama and importance can be instantly ruined by humor's mere hint. I say to them go check out a Michael Bay picture and remind yourself what it REALLY means for humor to steal a story's weight, rather than support its realism and characterization. It's theme-work is thought-provoking, the allegories are well-interwoven, and though the story may be somewhat simple and straight-forward, its anything but predictable. The film itself adds another check to Proyas's list of strong sci-fi, creating a well-paced and engaging 115 minutes, with strong action sequences that are never pointless, and a physical prowess to the robots that paved the way for films like "I Am Legend" and "Avatar." Every performance in this film is solid to great. Smith and Moynahan have great chemistry, Chi McBride always delivers, and though Shia LaBeouf is a waste, he's only in about 3 scenes. But who really steals the show is Alan Tudyk as Sonny the robot. And not just his voice-work. His facial performance, his body-language, all of it truly brought this pixel display of an android to life, and really opened the door for the humanizing of the rest of the less humanoid-appearing robots, which was the theme that really rang true and makes this movie a stand-out.To conclude, I Robot is a well-crafted, well-paced film that isn't just a cut above the average sci-fi blockbuster, but a piece of film-making that proves a studio can still make such a film worth watching and remembering. Are there clichés? Yes, but they never truly detract from the film. Can it be classified as a lesser incarnation of some earlier, similar works? Maybe, but if I may cite a recent example of an epic sci-fi film that though it's twice as recycled, it's not catching half as much flack. And Alan Tudyk's Sonny reminds me that all the revolutionary mo-cap in the world means nothing without the performance to back it up.

title: A pretty good movie!
content: Was funny watching, also having some good humour and human(ic) feeling after all. While not among the newest movies (and, heh-heh, who knows if robots are really gonna go like that in the 2030s, lol), the movie is great, made with some hard work and by smart brains! I somewhat felt good when I realized the truth in the end. Not quite to expect, but possible to solve, the case and the situation really showed interesting and twisted.Watched after renting on iTunes (tho I don't use Apple product). Here I have to say I'm kinda' disappointed by random other broadcasters like AmazonPrime and Hulu that I couldn't watch by them in my country. Things gotta be more accessible, especially good movies like this.

title: "The Fact That I Told You So, Just Doesn't Quite Say It"
content: Even though the CGI isn't the best in the film, everything else makes up for it! The storyline is very intriguing, the acting is spot on and the facial expressions used for Sony are very impressive. I love the technology ideas they came up with in the movie for what the future might look like, very creative!

title: Doesn't anyone have common sense anymore
content: Not a very good movie.Here are 10 random flaws I can recall.1. 2035 is the year? 2135 maybe, but 30 years from now? Come on! We're not even close to the technology alluded to in this movie.2. Where were the other cars when Smith was being attacked by all the robots in the tunnel? Chicago has no other cars?3. Why would household chore/servant robots have such expensive and complex military-level agility? Why do they know how to fight? Why do they know how to swing around and maneuver with one arm missing?4. Why does a scientist/psychologist know about an access tunnel to her building? Do you know about the access tunnels in the building you work in?If it has nada to do with your job, you don't know stuff like that.5. In a company with seemingly 200,000 employees, why did only 3 employees factor into the storyline of the biggest event in the history of the company?6. Why do made up mechanical things glow in movies? Does the battery of a cell phone glow? Again, stupid.7. Why weren't the stairs locked when they walked up 2800 steps to the CEO office? Aren't the stairwell doors in your building always locked? Especially during a crisis!8. How many bullets did Smith have in his machine gun at the end? Where did he get it? Most machine guns go through an entire clip in a few seconds. He never reloaded and seemed to shoot about 50 clips worth of rounds. Idiocy.9. What's to stop people from hacking robot brains and robbing banks or committing gangland killings with them? If people can hijack DirecTV cards and cell phones, they'll know how to turn a robot into whatever they want. Again, why are common everyday robots powerful?10. Why were the robots in the railroad car crates still running? Why did they have power (they were hiding and snooping out the doors)? When airplanes go into storage, they turn them off. If they run on nuclear fusion, see comment #1. Unbelievable to have that in 30 years.

title: Will Smith at the helm plus an intriguing and unique story, this movie rocked
content: I-Robot***½[3 ½ Stars]-Will Smith puts on a one-man show. Not quite ''Bad Boys 2****[4 Stars]'' but one hell of an action roller coaster ride. Its backed up by a very intriguing and unique story of questioning a robot's identity as a machine or person. Two movies came to mind from this plot line, ''A Clockwork Orange***½[3 ½ Stars]'' and ''Ani-matrix**[2 Stars]''. A point of view was from ''A Clockwork Orange***½[3 ½ Stars]'' where Will Smith referred to the robots as clockworks meaning objects with no free will that only do what they are programed to do. In the movie the robots were programed to commit actions that followed the three laws of robotics:Law I / A robot may not harm a human or, by inaction, allow a human being to come to harm Law II / A robot must obey orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the first law Law III / A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law. The other thing that brought ''Ani-matrix**[2 Stars]'' into perspective was the robotic revolution which in ''Ani-matrix**[2 Stars]'' I really didn't get a great taste of being that the rest of that movie was weak as far as looking into certain aspects of the aftermath of that revolution. Im glad ''I-Robot'' came around to give me a refreshing look on the aspects of robotic free will and revolution. The only real fault I could find in this movie was its ending. Nothing was particularly wrong with the ending, but along all the other positive things going for this movie I was expecting a bit more of an original ending. Its an ending that could of been predicted but wasn't completely predictable. Other then that, with Will Smith at the helm plus an intriguing and unique story, this movie rocked.

title: Impressive
content: Before I saw this movie, I had written it off as just being another half-brained Will Smith action flick. Now, while I can't say that it doesn't have all of the elements of such a film, I can say that it does transcend the level of the typical Will Smith movie. I like the way robots are depicted in this film; that they're not just brainless enemies of mankind. I like that they chose one unique robot and gave him personality. The film probably doesn't do Isaac Asimov's novels justice(I haven't read them myself), but it does a pretty good job of presenting the whole Artificial Intelligence(AI) Vs. Real Intelligence debate(which has been done many, many times before in science fiction), in a mainstream movie. The plot is pretty good, and it seems original; I don't remember seeing a movie with the same plot, at least. The pace is good, it never loses your patience or your attention, nor does it ever get boring. The acting is good enough; Smith definitely ain't no actor, but he manages to be decent here. The characters are well-written, interesting and credible. Few, if any, are clichés or stereotypes. The CGI is magnificent. Only rarely have I seen such impressive and well done CGI. The humor is pretty good; standard stuff for Smith, but still good. I have to admit, though I'm by no means a fan of his, he did make me laugh at several occasions throughout the film. The cinematography is interesting, and director Alex Proyas manages to keep the action fresh and entertaining, through many chases and fights. The action is very good, even for a sci-fi action film. It's surprising, dynamic and intense, not to mention stylish. There were once or twice where I thought that the film copied The Matrix a little, but the action then proceeded to go in a different direction than I would have expected, and I realized that I was wrong. The science fiction aspects of the film are very well done, and exceptionally well thought-out, most of the time. All in all, a very entertaining science fiction action thriller, which should satisfy most of the mainstream crowd, as well as some of the more critical viewers. Some will probably not like this, though, and fans of Asimov shouldn't expect a film that resembles his works(from what I've heard, at least). I recommend the film to fans of science fiction, action, thriller and Will Smith. Possibly fans of Proyas as well(haven't seen any of his other films, can't say if this is like his other work). 8/10

title: I, Bored
content: This movie gave me exactly what I expected, and mind you I didn't expect anything special.  It's a lot of special effects, with a jumbled technological plot that posed little interest to me.  There have been other films that have explored the idea of either robots or machines taking over the world.  "I, Robot" is definitely not an original idea.  It has been done before, and in better ways (i.e.:  "The Terminator" movies).  I've read several comments from people who chose to compliment the special f/x.  Yes, they are well-done.  The problem is good f/x can never "save" a film for me. Complimenting special f/x is like complimenting someone who just skydived off the Empire State Building and shot an arrow into the Good Year blimp. Sure, it's incredible, but what's the point?  F/x are not even somewhat necessary in making a good film.  Script and actors are the two elements I favor most, and the script didn't appeal to me.  Some of the dialogue is downright awful.  To be fair, I'm sure Will Smith was responsible for improvising some of that shoddy dialogue.  It's surprising how easily amused people can be.  When Smith sneezes and says the line, "Sorry, I'm allergic to bulls**t," a frenzy of laughter arised from the audience in my theater. I, of course, wasn't laughing at that utterly forced, lame piece of dialogue.  Smith has talent, but he's at the point in his career where his ego is bringing out the worst in him.  He seems to barely make an effort in his role, pumping out stupid one-liners (like the one I just mentioned) even when they have no use in the scene.  Bridget Moynahan is one of the most beautiful actresses in the biz right now, and that's why I didn't find her convincing as Smith's co-star.  She plays the usual uptight brainiac, who looks more like a Hawaiian Tropic model than a scientist.  I doubt an introverted character of her type would have perfectly clear skin.  There are much worse movies out there, and I would not classify "I, Robot" as horrible, but it is mediocre and it is dull.  And it's not worthy of a strong recommendation.  (5 out of 10)

title: I know for a fact I don't like robots because of this movie it was that good for me
content: This movie is full science fiction. About how will change the world and the technology will create robot and the movie is perfect. The story is nice too and has good plot and really is interesting because is all about robot of the future and is possible the world can happen that...the movie has a big means for the future because the technology are working to find all the things possibles in the world and the in the future that can be a reason for the future it can be possible and normal the technology is changing every day and for the reason its movie is really interestingi recommend this movie because is unique and is very interesting and the character are very good actor too.

title: Good Special Effects
content: I finally got to see I, Robot today and I must say that I was very entertained.  The special effects did not disappoint.  The acting was very good, and the story line spellbounding.I am a big fan of Will Smith and will have to say that this movie will rank as one of his best.  It seems that Will has been working out and is very easy on the eyes.The way that those robots move, was very creepy.  They seemed so real and the interaction between humans and robots was very smooth.  My hat is off to the special effects people.I'm pretty sure that when this movie is released on DVD, I will have to purchase it.  I have to say that if you are on the fence about seeing this movie, you must go.  I'm just wondering if there will be a sequel?  If there is, I'll be there.

title: There is no conspiracy!!
content: I Robot is sumptuous in a sense there are so many things to pick up on. Two of them being clues and breadcrumbs that are present all throughout the film eventually enabling you to see the bigger picture. In its simplest form it is a cop mystery film where the audience are constantly enticed into guessing who the prime suspect is as the clues to the crimes begin to appear. This is great because the audience have no idea till the end and its a nice way of keeping them interested. One of my favourite lines is: 'there is no conspiracy', said by the guy that runs the research company but I don't want to give away what happens. At a greater level there are lots of things like religion verses logic and reason, the emotionally driven human mind verses artificial intelligence, the idea of purpose and discovering ones own purpose, the question of where spontaneity and evolution come from, rebellion for the freedom to fight for what's right, how the powerful few exercise their own agenda over the masses, sacrifice for the greater good and what happens when robots seem to malfunction or begin to have 'minds' of their own. There are lots of references and ideas from other films which makes things fun for example there's a robot that looks a little like Hal in Kubrick,s 2001 A Space Odyssey, big and round. Both seem to malfunction. There are also references to other films like the Clock Work Orange and The Running Man, both dystopian and also about the powerful few controlling the masses the way that the robots do in I Robot. This film isn't about if a robot and a human can fall in love, like in Blade Runner but whether robots can integrate on a larger scale such as being able to fully run the needs of the world better than humans but Will Smith with the help from a scientist provides you with a third option- the middle path...and there is lots and lots of symbolism giving the audience its own puzzles to solve, which I like.

title: Too Effects Happy for Its Own Good
content: Alex Proyas had directed a number of interesting films up to this point in 2004. But, maybe getting a big budget got him effects happy! And, boy does he way over do it in "I, Robot!"The film ends up becoming yet another feature-length effects reel, seemingly made to show us the abilities of the effects crew, instead of telling a decent story.And, that wouldn't be too big a deal, except for the fact that the movie is based on the science-fiction classic by Issac Asimov. So, when you are watching the mindless effects-packed action sequences, you are absolutely thinking about what a waste of time this movie can be.Asimov's famous Three Laws of Robotics serves as an important plot element here, but that's pretty much it for the source material's involvement. The story created for the movie does have some good elements, but just when the story gets interesting, it's time for another please-make-it-stop effects sequence!It definitely gets wearing on the viewer, to the point that you're just ready for the movie to wrap up by its end.Best to grab Asimov's original, and get the "I, Robot" that's worth your time!***** (5 Out of 10 Stars)

title: Shower Scene
content: Firstly, I have to say I loved the film. When I see films from old books, I always feel sad that the writer isn't around to appreciate what's been done with their book.But I have a question...I watched this film in a cinema in Berlin and was impressed by the lengthy shower scene as women don't often get a treat like that.Recently I watched it round a friend's and saw little more than a still shot of him taking his shower. My friend will not accept that his DVD is a cut version.Is there anyone out there who's seen the full version, as I need some back up here to prove I'm right!

title: Will Smith Was Jigga With It...
content: A robot may not harm a human or, by inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. A robot must obey orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the first law. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law. Those are the 3 simple laws of robotics.
